{"timeCrawl": "05:21:00", "uri": "710691178", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:21:00Z", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "source": {"title": "Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "uri": "staradvertiser.com", "id": "872"}, "url": "http://www.staradvertiser.com/2017/08/16/breaking-news/trump-aide-no-military-solution-in-north-korea/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Steve Bannon, chief White House strategist to President Donald Trump is seen in Harrisburg, Pa. Bannon says there's no military solution to North Korea's threats and says the U.S. is losing the economic race against China.\n\nBRIDGEWATER, N.J. >> President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online today, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier today that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe president is under renewed pressure to fire Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. {"timeCrawl": "19:37:00", "uri": "711077298", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:57:00Z", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "source": {"title": "The Hollywood Reporter", "uri": "hollywoodreporter.com", "id": "4014"}, "url": "http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/steve-bannon-contradicts-trump-unusual-interview-1030469", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Bannon inititated the conversation, a move that left the reporter puzzled about \"probably the most media-savvy person in America.\"\n\nContradicting a boss already under pressure to fire him, President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions. Just last week, Trump pledged to answer North Korean aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China and talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nAsked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence, Bannon dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House and a representative for Bannon did not immediately respond to requests for comment on what is viewed as an unusual interview by one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle who is again facing an uncertain future in the White House.\n\nAccording to the writer, Robert Kuttner, Bannon called the reporter after his assistant had requested a meeting, much to Kuttner's surprise, in response to a column he had written on how China was profiting from the U.S.-North Korea escalation.\n\nWhen asked about his internal adversaries in the North Korean standoff, Bannon said \"they're wetting themselves.\"\n\nKuttner commented about how \"puzzling\" it was for Bannon to call an editor of a progressive publication and never bring up whether the conversation was on or off the record, since Bannon is \"not exactly Bambi when it comes to dealing with the press\" and is \"probably the most media-savvy person in America.\"\n\nA source close to Bannon told CNN he did not believe he was being interviewed on record when they spoke.\n\nTrump passed up an opportunity this week to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon, who was a key campaign adviser during the general election and has become a forceful presence in a divided White House. But the former leader of the conservative Breitbart News has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump finds himself increasingly isolated, except among his core supporters, for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault in Charlottesville.\n\nOthers believe Bannon is behind a campaign conservative groups and the Breitbart website are waging against national security adviser H.R. McMaster, arguing he is insufficiently supportive of Israel and soft on Iran. Trump recently issued a rare public statement of support for McMaster.\n\nBannon's comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that Bannon was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and that he guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted early Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade -- without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday that both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked at a regular news briefing about Bannon's comments, Hua said \"there is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his stance on China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. {"timeCrawl": "11:03:00", "uri": "710836208", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T01:22:00Z", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "source": {"title": "The Fresno Bee", "uri": "fresnobee.com", "id": "10515"}, "url": "http://www.fresnobee.com/news/business/article167650437.html", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe president is under renewed pressure to fire Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. {"timeCrawl": "03:48:00", "uri": "710663522", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T03:48:00Z", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/trump-aide-no-military-solution-in-north-korea/articleshow/60096277.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER(NJ): President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury\".\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the US is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the US territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the US to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented US trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe president is under renewed pressure to fire Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", "id": "9605703", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "13:11:00", "uri": "710895178", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:11:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "Edmonton Sun", "uri": "edmontonsun.com", "id": "1063"}, "url": "http://www.edmontonsun.com/2017/08/17/steve-bannon-no-military-solution-in-north-korea-white-supremacists-are-losers?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=recommend-button&utm_campaign=Steve Bannon: No military solution in North Korea, white supremacists are 'losers'", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. -- President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defence and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\nIt's highly unusual for Bannon, one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle, to give a lengthy interview to a journalist, much less one from a liberal publication.\n\nHis comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favour with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that he was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked about Bannon's comments, Hua said at a regular new briefing, \"There is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. {"timeCrawl": "01:50:00", "uri": "711203389", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T22:00:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "St. Louis Post-Dispatch", "uri": "stltoday.com", "id": "1117"}, "url": "http://www.stltoday.com/news/national/trump-aide-no-military-solution-in-north-korea/article_8123828d-1bc4-55a1-a505-420f58afbf14.html", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) -- President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe president is under renewed pressure to fire Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"\n\n-- -- --\n\nFollow Darlene Superville on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/dsupervilleap", "id": "9807208", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Trump aide: No {"timeCrawl": "13:02:00", "uri": "710890111", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:02:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "Daily Chronicle", "uri": "daily-chronicle.com", "id": "3427"}, "url": "http://www.daily-chronicle.com/2017/08/17/bannon-no-military-solution-in-north-korea/arcrjwd/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. -- President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\nIt's highly unusual for Bannon, one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle, to give a lengthy interview to a journalist, much less one from a liberal publication.\n\nHis comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that he was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked about Bannon's comments, Hua said at a regular new briefing, \"There is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. {"timeCrawl": "12:52:00", "uri": "710886291", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:52:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "North Bay Nugget", "uri": "nugget.ca", "id": "9901"}, "url": "http://www.nugget.ca/2017/08/17/steve-bannon-no-military-solution-in-north-korea-white-supremacists-are-losers", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. -- President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defence and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\nIt's highly unusual for Bannon, one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle, to give a lengthy interview to a journalist, much less one from a liberal publication.\n\nHis comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favour with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that he was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked about Bannon's comments, Hua said at a regular new briefing, \"There is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"", "id": "9690497", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Bannon talks N. {"timeCrawl": "19:29:00", "uri": "711074205", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T11:58:00Z", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "source": {"title": "Eagle-Tribune", "uri": "eagletribune.com", "id": "135"}, "url": "http://www.eagletribune.com/news/president-s-aide-u-s-has-no-military-solution-to/article_496ddc46-8346-11e7-8bc4-9f53da898e96.html", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) -- President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon said there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon told the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked about Bannon's comments, Hua said at a regular new briefing, \"There is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe president is under renewed pressure to fire Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"", "id": "9762961", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "President's aide: U.S. has no military solution to North Korean threat", "image": (AP) -- President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe president is under renewed pressure to fire Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"\n\n___\n\nFollow Darlene Superville on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/dsupervilleap\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"timeCrawl": "11:05:00", "uri": "710837865", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T11:05:00Z", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "source": {"title": "The Bulletin", "uri": "norwichbulletin.com", "id": "593"}, "url": "http://www.norwichbulletin.com/news/20170817/trump-aide-no-military-solution-in-north-korea?rssfeed=true", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. -- President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked about Bannon's comments, Hua said at a regular new briefing, \"There is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe president is under renewed pressure to fire Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. {"timeCrawl": "14:07:00", "uri": "710923558", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T14:07:00Z", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "source": {"title": "Aurora Sentinel", "uri": "aurorasentinel.com", "id": "2965"}, "url": "http://www.aurorasentinel.com/news/nation-world/trump-strategist-steve-bannon-no-military-solution-north-korea/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. | President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\nIt's highly unusual for Bannon, one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle, to give a lengthy interview to a journalist, much less one from a liberal publication.\n\nHis comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that he was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked about Bannon's comments, Hua said at a regular new briefing, \"There is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"\n\n___\n\nFollow Darlene Superville on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/dsupervilleap", "id": "9705440", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Trump strategist Steve {"timeCrawl": "12:42:00", "uri": "710881244", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:36:00Z", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "source": {"title": "Associated Press", "uri": "hosted.ap.org", "id": "963"}, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_BANNON_INTERVIEW_ASOL-?SITE=CAANR&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) -- President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\nIt's highly unusual for Bannon, one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle, to give a lengthy interview to a journalist, much less one from a liberal publication.\n\nHis comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that he was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked about Bannon's comments, Hua said at a regular new briefing, \"There is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"\n\n---\n\nFollow Darlene Superville on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/dsupervilleap", "id": "9688122", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Trump aide: No military {"timeCrawl": "12:58:00", "uri": "710888571", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:58:00Z", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "source": {"title": "newschannel10.com", "uri": "newschannel10.com", "id": "8841"}, "url": "http://www.newschannel10.com/story/36155054/trump-aide-no-military-solution-in-north-korea", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) - President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\nIt's highly unusual for Bannon, one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle, to give a lengthy interview to a journalist, much less one from a liberal publication.\n\nHis comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that he was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked about Bannon's comments, Hua said at a regular new briefing, \"There is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"\n\n___\n\nFollow Darlene Superville on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/dsupervilleap\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"timeCrawl": "08:40:00", "uri": "710773188", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:40:00Z", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "source": {"title": "The Financial Express", "uri": "financialexpress.com", "id": "4684"}, "url": "http://www.financialexpress.com/world-news/steve-bannon-tells-magazine-about-his-white-house-feuds-over-china/812151/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "White House chief strategist Steve Bannon told a journalist about his long-simmering feud with some of President Donald Trump's top economic advisers.\n\nWhite House chief strategist Steve Bannon told a journalist about his long-simmering feud with some of President Donald Trump's top economic advisers, saying in an interview with The American Prospect that he battles them often, especially over his determination to take a tougher position on China. Bannon never intended for his conversation with the magazine's co-editor Robert Kuttner to be published, according to a person familiar with Bannon who asked not to be identified. The publication comes as there is speculation that Bannon's job is peril, reportedly over Trump's discomfort with the credit Bannon gets for being the intellectual force behind the administration.\n\nLast month, White House communications director Anthony Scaramucci was removed just 10 days into the job after Scaramucci made lewd comments about Bannon and others in an interview with the New Yorker that he also later said was meant to be off the record. According to Kuttner, Bannon told him he reached out because he agreed with Kuttner's past writings on China. Bannon rarely speaks with reporters on the record, let alone a liberal-leaning magazine.\n\nYou May Also Like To Watch:\n\nIn a telephone interview, Kuttner said the issue of whether his conversation with Bannon was off the record never came up, even indirectly. \"He phoned and began by saying how much he agreed with my work on trade and it just went from there. He knows the rules. It's on the record unless someone puts it off.\"\"That's a fight I fight every day here,\" Bannon is quoted as saying in the interview about his fueds with other senior officials over China. He pointed to fellow Goldman Sachs Group Inc. alumni, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn, who are pushing for a softer stance on trade with China. \"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying.\"\n\nThe interview comes as the White House has struggled to respond to Saturday's violent racial protests in Charlottesville, Virginia and as some aides -- including Cohn -- have objected in private to Trump's restrained denunciations of white supremacists. Bannon approved of the president's approach, said officials in the administration who asked not to be named. Bannon did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon said his rivals in the administration are \"wetting themselves\" as he works to undermine their influence with the president and he bragged about working to get some of them ousted. There has been speculation in recent days that Bannon could be in danger of losing his job, though Trump spoke in supportive terms about about him at Tuesday's press conference.\n\nBannon said he favors pushing back against Chinese economic expansion, arguing only one country will emerge as a leader from what he described as an \"economic war.\" \"To me, the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, ten years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" he said.\n\nHe advocated for the U.S. to file a complaint under Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act -- which allows for sanctions against countries that violate trade agreements or engage in unfair trade practices -- as well as follow-up complaints against steel and aluminum dumping, Kuttner wrote.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" Bannon said.\n\nBannon also dismissed speculation that the U.S might consider using military action against North Korea to get the regime there to abandon its intercontinental ballistic missile and nuclear weapon programs. Trump recently vowed to deliver \"fire and fury\" onto North Korea.\n\n\"There's no military solution, forget it,\" Bannon said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that ten million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon also dismissed the so called far-right that he helped organize and inflame when he led Breitbart News and during Trump's 2016 campaign.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he said. \"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nStill, Bannon said he's fine with the issue of race taking over the national conversation. \"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em,\" he is quoted as saying. \"I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"", "id": "9644478", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Steve Bannon tells {"timeCrawl": "10:24:00", "uri": "710818229", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T09:39:00Z", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "source": {"title": "Associated Press", "uri": "hosted2.ap.org", "id": "566"}, "url": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/6b85546689744819aa7a64cd3ca6cee6/Article_2017-08-17-US--Bannon-Interview/id-026b0bb8508348de96b13d9e382d8f60", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) -- President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked about Bannon's comments, Hua said at a regular new briefing, \"There is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe president is under renewed pressure to fire Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. (AP) -- President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\nSponsored Content: How is your agency managing and maximizing its data? Share your opinions in a Federal News Radio survey.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked about Bannon's comments, Hua said at a regular new briefing, \"There is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe president is under renewed pressure to fire Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. {"timeCrawl": "11:57:00", "uri": "710860161", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:49:00Z", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "source": {"title": "The Denver Post", "uri": "denverpost.com", "id": "138"}, "url": "http://www.denverpost.com/2017/08/17/steve-bannon-american-prospect-interview/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "White House chief strategist Steve Bannon told a journalist about his long-simmering feud with some of President Donald Trump's top economic advisers, saying in an interview with The American Prospect that he battles them often, especially over his determination to take a tougher position on China.\n\nBannon never intended for his conversation with the magazine's co-editor Robert Kuttner to be published, according to a person familiar with Bannon who asked not to be identified. The publication comes as there is speculation that Bannon's job is peril, reportedly over Trump's discomfort with the credit Bannon gets for being the intellectual force behind the administration.\n\nLast month, White House communications director Anthony Scaramucci was removed just 10 days into the job after Scaramucci made lewd comments about Bannon and others in an interview with the New Yorker that he also later said was meant to be off the record.\n\nAccording to Kuttner, Bannon told him he reached out because he agreed with Kuttner's past writings on China. Bannon rarely speaks with reporters on the record, let alone a liberal-leaning magazine.\n\nIn a telephone interview, Kuttner said the issue of whether his conversation with Bannon was off the record never came up, even indirectly. \"He phoned and began by saying how much he agreed with my work on trade and it just went from there. He knows the rules. It's on the record unless someone puts it off.\"\n\n\"That's a fight I fight every day here,\" Bannon is quoted as saying in the interview about his feuds with other senior officials over China. He pointed to fellow Goldman Sachs alumni, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn, who are pushing for a softer stance on trade with China. \"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying.\"\n\nThe interview comes as the White House has struggled to respond to Saturday's violent racial protests in Charlottesville, Virginia and as some aides -- including Cohn -- have objected in private to Trump's restrained denunciations of white supremacists. Bannon approved of the president's approach, said officials in the administration who asked not to be named. Bannon did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon said his rivals in the administration are \"wetting themselves\" as he works to undermine their influence with the president and he bragged about working to get some of them ousted. There has been speculation in recent days that Bannon could be in danger of losing his job, though Trump spoke in supportive terms about about him at Tuesday's press conference.\n\nBannon said he favors pushing back against Chinese economic expansion, arguing only one country will emerge as a leader from what he described as an \"economic war.\"\n\n\"To me, the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" he said.\n\nHe advocated for the U.S. to file a complaint under Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act -- which allows for sanctions against countries that violate trade agreements or engage in unfair trade practices -- as well as follow-up complaints against steel and aluminum dumping, Kuttner wrote.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" Bannon said.\n\nBannon also dismissed speculation that the U.S might consider using military action against North Korea to get the regime there to abandon its intercontinental ballistic missile and nuclear weapon programs. Trump recently vowed to deliver \"fire and fury\" onto North Korea.\n\n\"There's no military solution, forget it,\" Bannon said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that ten million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon also dismissed the so called far-right that he helped organize and inflame when he led Breitbart News and during Trump's 2016 campaign.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism - it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he said. \"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nStill, Bannon said he's fine with the issue of race taking over the national conversation. \"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em,\" he is quoted as saying. \"I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"", "id": "9679805", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Steve Bannon says
