{"timeCrawl": "02:27:00", "uri": "710641987", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T02:14:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/aug/17/steve-bannon-calls-far-right-losers-trump-warns-china-trade-war-american-prospect", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "White House chief strategist Steve Bannon has given an unusual interview in which he claimed there was no military solution for North Korea, the far right was a \"collection of clowns\" and the left's focus on racism would allow him to \"crush the Democrats\".\n\nBannon, who has been called the mastermind behind Donald Trump's nationalist agenda, made the controversial and unsolicited remarks to Robert Kuttner, co-founder and co-editor of the American Prospect, a leftwing political magazine, in an interview published Wednesday.\n\nThe seemingly candid comments - which included the claims that he would oust his rivals in the federal government, who were \"wetting themselves\" - come at a time when Bannon faces an uncertain future at the White House. There have been increasing calls from the left and the right for the removal of the former editor of Breitbart News. When Trump was asked at a press conference this week if the chief strategist would remain in his position, the president said: \"We'll see.\"\n\nIt is unclear why Bannon chose to call Kuttner, who wrote that he had not requested the interview and was \"stunned\" to hear from him. However after publication stories circulated that Bannon was unaware he was providing an interview.\n\nThere have been recent reports of internal conflicts and power struggles within the administration, and Bannon made the call amid an intense backlash related to Trump's links to the far right and the president's comments that there were \"very fine people\" at a violent white nationalist protest in Charlottesville.\n\nIn the American Prospect story, headlined \"Steve Bannon, unrepentant\", Trump's top aide said: \"We're at economic war with China. It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"\n\nContradicting Trump's threats of \"fire and fury\" on North Korea, Bannon said: \"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it. Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nBannon also discussed his \"battle inside the administration to take a harder line on China trade\", Kuttner wrote. Asked about his adversaries at the US departments of state and defense, Bannon responded, \"Oh, they're wetting themselves.\"\n\nHe continued: \"I'm changing out people at east Asian defense; I'm getting hawks in. I'm getting Susan Thornton [acting head of east Asian and Pacific affairs] out at state.\"\n\nThe State Department and the White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment on Wednesday night. At the time of writing Susan Thornton was still listed in her position.\n\nKuttner also asked Bannon about the \"ugly white nationalism epitomized by the racist violence in Charlottesville and Trump's reluctance to condemn it\". Heather Heyer, a civil rights activist, was killed when a man alleged to be a white nationalist drove a car into a crowd of counter protesters on Saturday.\n\nBannon dismissed the far right as \"irrelevant\", Kuttner wrote, quoting the Trump aide as saying: \"Ethno-nationalism - it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more ... These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nRegarding the Democrats, Bannon said: \"The longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em. I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"\n\nKuttner wrote that he had never spoken to Bannon before and that the question of whether the call was on or off the record never came up.\n\nAnthony Scaramucci, Trump's short-lived communications director, was recently fired after he called up a reporter and launched a foul-mouthed rant against senior colleagues, including Bannon.\n\nBannon has attracted significant controversy during his time at the White House, where he was blamed for the failed implementation of the travel ban, which was quickly blocked by the courts.\n\nIt has been reported that the president's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, and his wife, Ivanka Trump, have long urged Bannon's dismissal.\n\nThe president tried to downplay Bannon's influence on his campaign at the recent press conference, saying, \"I like Mr Bannon. He's a friend of mine. Just last week, Trump pledged to answer North Korean aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China and talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nAsked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence, Bannon dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House and a representative for Bannon did not immediately respond to requests for comment on what is viewed as an unusual interview by one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle who is again facing an uncertain future in the White House.\n\nTrump passed up an opportunity this week to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon, who was a key campaign adviser during the general election and has become a forceful presence in a divided White House. But the former leader of the conservative Breitbart News has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump finds himself increasingly isolated, except among his core supporters, for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault in Charlottesville.\n\nOthers believe Bannon is behind a campaign conservative groups and the Breitbart website are waging against national security adviser H.R. McMaster, arguing he is insufficiently supportive of Israel and soft on Iran. Trump recently issued a rare public statement of support for McMaster.\n\nBannon's comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that Bannon was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and that he guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted early Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade -- without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday that both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked at a regular news briefing about Bannon's comments, Hua said \"there is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his stance on China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. {"timeCrawl": "12:36:00", "uri": "710878494", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:36:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"title": "Capitol Hill Blue", "uri": "capitolhillblue.com", "id": "5920"}, "url": "https://www.capitolhillblue.com/node/67647", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked about Bannon's comments, Hua said at a regular new briefing, \"There is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe president is under renewed pressure to fire Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"\n\n___\n\nFollow Darlene Superville on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/dsupervilleap\n\n_______________________________________________________\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2017 Capitol Hill Blue\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2017 The Associated Press. {"timeCrawl": "01:02:00", "uri": "710620303", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T01:02:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"title": "CBS News", "uri": "cbsnews.com", "id": "166"}, "url": "http://www.cbsnews.com/news/his-future-in-jeopardy-bannon-attacks-administration-rivals/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "President Trump's embattled chief strategist Steve Bannon lashed out at his rivals in the administration in a rare interview with the American Prospect, which was published Wednesday.\n\nBannon told progressive American Prospect writer Robert Kuttner about his plan to neutralize his opponents, which include top officials and advisers to President Trump.\n\n\"They're wetting themselves,\" he said of his adversaries in the administration who disagree with him on trade and economic policies.\n\nBannon proceeded to relay how he wants to create an outside group of trade hawks with factions from both the left and the right wings of the political spectrum. Bannon told Kuttner he's \"changing out people at East Asian Defense,\" and getting Susan Thornton, the acting head of East Asian and Pacific Affairs for the State Department, \"out at State.\"\n\n\"That's a fight I fight every day here,\" he said. \"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and [National Economic Council chair] Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this,\" Bannon continued about taking an aggressive stance against China on trade issues. \"The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy. Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"\n\n\"To me, the economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon told Kuttner. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, ten years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon's call to Kuttner, who says he'd never spoken to the former Breitbart publisher before, came as Bannon's future in the White House is uncertain. On Tuesday, Mr. Trump said \"we'll see\" what happens with Bannon, in the middle of a chaotic press that blamed \"both sides\" for violence in Charlottesville, Virginia, over the weekend.\n\n\"Well we'll see - look, like, I like Mr. Bannon, he's a friend of mine, but Mr. Bannon came on very late, you know that,\" Mr. Trump said. \"I went through 17 senators, governors, and I won all the primaries. Mr. Bannon came on very much later than that, and I like him, he is a good man, he is not a racist, I can tell you that. He's a good person. He actually gets a very unfair press in that regard, but we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon, but he's a good person, and I think the press treats him frankly very unfairly.\"\n\nBannon, who in the past has bragged about his connections to the \"alt-right,\" dismissed the far-right protesters as an irrelevant \"fringe element.\"\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers,\" Bannon said. \"It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more.\"\n\n\"These guys are a collection of clowns,\" the president's chief strategist added.\n\nBannon also said pursuing a military option with North Korea in the face of its nuclear threats is useless.\n\n\"There's no military solution, forget it,\" Bannon said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul [South Korea] don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military {"timeCrawl": "01:58:00", "uri": "710633519", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T01:58:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"title": "Houston Chronicle", "uri": "houstonchronicle.com", "id": "6296"}, "url": "http://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/article/Trump-aide-No-military-solution-in-North-Korea-11824807.php", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) -- President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China. He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe president is under renewed pressure to fire Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump.\n\nEarlier this week, the president passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"\n\n___\n\nFollow Darlene Superville on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/dsupervilleap", "id": "9595737", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Trump aide: No military Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. {"timeCrawl": "07:09:00", "uri": "710732464", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:09:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "The Times of Israel", "uri": "timesofisrael.com", "id": "380"}, "url": "http://www.timesofisrael.com/trump-aide-bannon-says-white-nationalist-clowns-need-to-be-crushed/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, New Jersey -- US President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon dismissed the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence, as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon talked about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments and told the liberal publication that the US is losing the economic race against China.\n\nBannon also said there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\nBannon, a campaign adviser reportedly under internal pressure in the White House, is largely seen as having played a key role in the rise of the so-called alt-right movement of white nationalists, white supremacists and other racist groups that rallied in Virginia Saturday, many of whom turned up in neo-Nazi regalia and bearing shields and burning torches to defend a statue of Civil War general Robert E. Lee -- a hero of the slave-holding Confederacy..\n\nBut in the interview, Bannon seemed to dismiss the groups as fringe elements, and blamed the media for giving them outsized coverage.\n\nHundreds of white nationalists, neo-Nazis and members of the \"alt-right\" march down East Market Street toward Lee Park during the \"Unite the Right\" rally August 12, 2017 in Charlottesville, Virginia. (Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images/AFP)\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he's quoted saying. \"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nTrump has come under fire at home and abroad for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia. The statements, including a contentious Tuesday press conference during which he insisted that \"both sides\" were at fault, have been widely seen as giving support to white supremacist groups, many of whose leaders have expressed satisfaction with the president.\n\nAccording to a report from insider news platform Axios, Bannon has been delighted by Trump's statements -- dubbing them a victory for the nationalist camp in the White House over the \"globalists\" he fears are trying to drag the president towards a conventional line.\n\nIn this April 9, 2017, file photo, White House chief strategist Steve Bannon steps off Air Force One at Andrews Air Force Base, Md. (AP/Alex Brandon)\n\nAs the head of the Brietbart news organization, Bannon gave white nationalism a high-profile platform, and his senior position with Trump is regarded as a sign of close ties between the movement and the administration.\n\nA forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe president is under renewed pressure to fire Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump.\n\nAt the Tuesday press conference, the president also passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nMuch of the interview was devoted to Bannon's platform of economic nationalism and tensions with North Korea.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon mused about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his strategy toward China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon said. \"Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"\n\nUS President Donald Trump, senior advisor Jared Kushner, Director of the National Economic Council Gary Cohen, and Chief Strategist Stephen Bannon are seen during a bilateral meeting with the Saudi crown prince (not in photo) at a hotel in Riyadh on May 20, 2017. (AFP Photo/Mandel Ngan)\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon added. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the US territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the US to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented US trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon said. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nAFP contributed to this report.", "id": {"timeCrawl": "13:51:00", "uri": "710915822", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:51:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "kentucky", "uri": "kentucky.com", "id": "9968"}, "url": "http://www.kentucky.com/latest-news/article167682917.html", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Contradicting a boss already under pressure to fire him, President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions. Just last week, Trump pledged to answer North Korean aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China and talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nAsked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence, Bannon dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House and a representative for Bannon did not immediately respond to requests for comment on what is viewed as an unusual interview by one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle who is again facing an uncertain future in the White House.\n\nTrump passed up an opportunity this week to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon, who was a key campaign adviser during the general election and has become a forceful presence in a divided White House. But the former leader of the conservative Breitbart News has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump finds himself increasingly isolated, except among his core supporters, for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault in Charlottesville.\n\nOthers believe Bannon is behind a campaign conservative groups and the Breitbart website are waging against national security adviser H.R. McMaster, arguing he is insufficiently supportive of Israel and soft on Iran. Trump recently issued a rare public statement of support for McMaster.\n\nBannon's comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that Bannon was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and that he guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted early Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade -- without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday that both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked at a regular news briefing about Bannon's comments, Hua said \"there is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his stance on China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. {"timeCrawl": "13:59:00", "uri": "710919162", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:59:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "canoe.com", "uri": "cnews.canoe.com", "id": "10886"}, "url": "http://cnews.canoe.com/CNEWS/World/2017/08/17/22746065.html", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. -- President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the president's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China and talks about purging his rivals from the Defence and State departments.\n\nAsked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence, Bannon dismisses them as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House and a representative for Bannon did not immediately respond to requests for comment on what is viewed as an unusual interview by one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle who is again facing an uncertain future in the White House.\n\nTrump passed up an opportunity this week to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon, who was a key campaign adviser during the general election and has become a forceful presence in a divided White House. But the former leader of the conservative Breitbart News has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump finds himself increasingly isolated, except among his core supporters, for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault in Charlottesville.\n\nOthers believe Bannon is behind a campaign conservative groups and the Breitbart website are waging against national security adviser H.R. McMaster, arguing he is insufficiently supportive of Israel and soft on Iran. Trump recently issued a rare public statement of support for McMaster.\n\nBannon's comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favour with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that Bannon was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and that he guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted early Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade -- without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday that both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked at a regular news briefing about Bannon's comments, Hua said \"there is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his stance on China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. {"timeCrawl": "19:42:00", "uri": "711079341", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:42:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"title": "Hamodia", "uri": "hamodia.com", "id": "3374"}, "url": "http://hamodia.com/2017/08/17/bannon-no-military-solution-north-korea/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) - Contradicting a boss already under pressure to fire him, President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions. Just last week, Trump pledged to answer North Korean aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China and talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nAsked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence, Bannon dismisses them as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nA White House spokeswoman said \"Bannon's comments stand on their own.\"\n\nIn a separate interview with the DailyMail.com, Bannon said that his comments to The American Prospect \"drew fire away from\" Trump and that he successfully \"changed the (media) narrative\" around Trump with the earlier interview.\n\nBannon, one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle, is again facing an uncertain future in the White House, a situation that could be further complicated by his decision to give the initial interview.\n\nTrump passed up an opportunity this week to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon, who was a key campaign adviser during the general election and has become a forceful presence in a divided White House. But the former leader of the conservative Breitbart News has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump finds himself increasingly isolated, except among his core supporters, for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault in Charlottesville.\n\nOthers believe Bannon is behind a campaign conservative group, and the Breitbart website is waging against national security adviser H.R. McMaster, arguing that he is insufficiently supportive of Israel and soft on Iran. Trump recently issued a rare public statement of support for McMaster.\n\nBannon's comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that Bannon was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and that he guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about; there's no military solution here -- they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted early Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade -- without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think -- 10 years at the most -- of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday that both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked at a regular news briefing about Bannon's comments, Hua said \"there is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his stance on China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says.\n\nOne official Bannon mentioned by name is Susan Thornton, currently America's top diplomat for Asia.\n\nOn Thursday, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson signaled support for his senior adviser. {"timeCrawl": "17:10:00", "uri": "711014720", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T17:10:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"title": "KSNT News", "uri": "ksnt.com", "id": "2852"}, "url": "http://ksnt.com/2017/08/17/trump-aide-no-military-solution-in-north-korea/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) -- Contradicting a boss already under pressure to fire him, President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions. Just last week, Trump pledged to answer North Korean aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China and talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nAsked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence, Bannon dismisses them as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nA White House spokeswoman said \"Bannon's comments stand on their own.\"\n\nIn a separate interview with the DailyMail.com, Bannon said his comments to The American Prospect \"drew fire away from\" Trump and that he successfully \"changed the (media) narrative\" around Trump with the earlier interview.\n\nBannon, one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle, is again facing an uncertain future in the White House, a situation that could be further complicated by his decision to give the initial interview.\n\nTrump passed up an opportunity this week to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon, who was a key campaign adviser during the general election and has become a forceful presence in a divided White House. But the former leader of the conservative Breitbart News has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump finds himself increasingly isolated, except among his core supporters, for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault in Charlottesville.\n\nOthers believe Bannon is behind a campaign conservative groups and the Breitbart website are waging against national security adviser H.R. McMaster, arguing he is insufficiently supportive of Israel and soft on Iran. Trump recently issued a rare public statement of support for McMaster.\n\nBannon's comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that Bannon was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and that he guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted early Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade -- without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday that both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked at a regular news briefing about Bannon's comments, Hua said \"there is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his stance on China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says.\n\nOne official Bannon mentioned by name is Susan Thornton, currently America's top diplomat for Asia.\n\nOn Thursday, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson signaled support for his senior adviser. After greeting Japan's defense chief and top diplomat at the State Department, Tillerson pointedly shook Thornton's hand in front of the cameras as their meeting began.", "id": "9741139", "details": {"timeCrawl": "15:35:00", "uri": "710966509", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:35:00Z", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "source": {"title": "The Carthage Press", "uri": "carthagepress.com", "id": "1514"}, "url": "http://www.carthagepress.com/zz/news/20170817/steve-bannon-no-military-solution-in-north-korea?rssfeed=true", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Contradicting a boss already under pressure to fire him, President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions. Just last week, Trump pledged to answer North Korean aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nBRIDGEWATER, N.J. -- Contradicting a boss already under pressure to fire him, President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions. Just last week, Trump pledged to answer North Korean aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China and talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nAsked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence, Bannon dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House and a representative for Bannon did not immediately respond to requests for comment on what is viewed as an unusual interview by one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle who is again facing an uncertain future in the White House.\n\nTrump passed up an opportunity this week to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon, who was a key campaign adviser during the general election and has become a forceful presence in a divided White House. But the former leader of the conservative Breitbart News has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump finds himself increasingly isolated, except among his core supporters, for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault in Charlottesville.\n\nOthers believe Bannon is behind a campaign conservative groups and the Breitbart website are waging against national security adviser H.R. McMaster, arguing he is insufficiently supportive of Israel and soft on Iran. Trump recently issued a rare public statement of support for McMaster.\n\nBannon's comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that Bannon was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and that he guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted early Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade -- without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday that both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked at a regular news briefing about Bannon's comments, Hua said \"there is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his stance on China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. {"timeCrawl": "07:56:00", "uri": "710752462", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:56:00Z", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "source": {"title": "msn.com", "uri": "msn.com", "id": "152"}, "url": "http://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/world/bannon-tells-magazine-about-his-white-house-feuds-over-china/ar-AAqe4vc", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "\u00a9 Jennifer Epstein BC-BANNON-MAG-INTERVIEW-1 (Bloomberg) -- White House chief strategist Steve Bannon told a journalist about his long-simmering feud with some of President Donald Trump's top economic advisers, saying in an interview with The American Prospect that he battles them often, especially over his determination to take a tougher position on China.\n\nBannon never intended for his conversation with the magazine's co-editor Robert Kuttner to be published, according to a person familiar with Bannon who asked not to be identified. The publication comes as there is speculation that Bannon's job is peril, reportedly over Trump's discomfort with the credit Bannon gets for being the intellectual force behind the administration.\n\nLast month, White House communications director Anthony Scaramucci was removed just 10 days into the job after Scaramucci made lewd comments about Bannon and others in an interview with the New Yorker that he also later said was meant to be off the record.\n\nAccording to Kuttner, Bannon told him he reached out because he agreed with Kuttner's past writings on China. Bannon rarely speaks with reporters on the record, let alone a liberal-leaning magazine.\n\nIn a telephone interview, Kuttner said the issue of whether his conversation with Bannon was off the record never came up, even indirectly. \"He phoned and began by saying how much he agreed with my work on trade and it just went from there. He knows the rules. It's on the record unless someone puts it off.\"\n\n\"That's a fight I fight every day here,\" Bannon is quoted as saying in the interview about his fueds with other senior officials over China. He pointed to fellow Goldman Sachs Group Inc. alumni, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn, who are pushing for a softer stance on trade with China. \"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying.\"\n\nThe interview comes as the White House has struggled to respond to Saturday's violent racial protests in Charlottesville, Virginia and as some aides -- including Cohn -- have objected in private to Trump's restrained denunciations of white supremacists. Bannon approved of the president's approach, said officials in the administration who asked not to be named. Bannon did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon said his rivals in the administration are \"wetting themselves\" as he works to undermine their influence with the president and he bragged about working to get some of them ousted. There has been speculation in recent days that Bannon could be in danger of losing his job, though Trump spoke in supportive terms about about him at Tuesday's press conference.\n\nBannon said he favors pushing back against Chinese economic expansion, arguing only one country will emerge as a leader from what he described as an \"economic war.\"\n\n\"To me, the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, ten years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" he said.\n\nHe advocated for the U.S. to file a complaint under Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act -- which allows for sanctions against countries that violate trade agreements or engage in unfair trade practices -- as well as follow-up complaints against steel and aluminum dumping, Kuttner wrote.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" Bannon said.\n\nBannon also dismissed speculation that the U.S might consider using military action against North Korea to get the regime there to abandon its intercontinental ballistic missile and nuclear weapon programs. Trump recently vowed to deliver \"fire and fury\" onto North Korea.\n\n\"There's no military solution, forget it,\" Bannon said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that ten million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon also dismissed the so called far-right that he helped organize and inflame when he led Breitbart News and during Trump's 2016 campaign.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he said. \"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nStill, Bannon said he's fine with the issue of race taking over the national conversation. \"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em,\" he is quoted as saying. \"I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"\n\n--With assistance from Margaret Talev", "id": "9636614", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "14:10:00", "uri": "710924154", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:13:00Z", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "source": {"title": "San Francisco Chronicle", "uri": "sfchronicle.com", "id": "2142"}, "url": "http://www.sfchronicle.com/news/politics/article/Trump-aide-No-military-solution-in-North-Korea-11839726.php", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) -- Contradicting a boss already under pressure to fire him, President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions. Just last week, Trump pledged to answer North Korean aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China and talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nAsked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence, Bannon dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House and a representative for Bannon did not immediately respond to requests for comment on what is viewed as an unusual interview by one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle who is again facing an uncertain future in the White House.\n\nTrump passed up an opportunity this week to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon, who was a key campaign adviser during the general election and has become a forceful presence in a divided White House. But the former leader of the conservative Breitbart News has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump finds himself increasingly isolated, except among his core supporters, for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault in Charlottesville.\n\nOthers believe Bannon is behind a campaign conservative groups and the Breitbart website are waging against national security adviser H.R. McMaster, arguing he is insufficiently supportive of Israel and soft on Iran. Trump recently issued a rare public statement of support for McMaster.\n\nBannon's comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that Bannon was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and that he guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted early Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade -- without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday that both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked at a regular news briefing about Bannon's comments, Hua said \"there is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his stance on China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says. \"Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"\n\n___\n\nFollow Darlene Superville on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/dsupervilleap", "id": "9705723", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Trump aide: No military {"timeCrawl": "19:28:00", "uri": "711072427", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:28:00Z", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "source": {"title": "The New Civil Rights Movement", "uri": "thenewcivilrightsmovement.com", "id": "3246"}, "url": "http://www.thenewcivilrightsmovement.com/davidbadash/_this_is_defcon_1_level_bad_steve_bannon_accused_of_giving_interview_casually_undermining_us_national_security", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "White House Chief Strategist Steve Bannon on Wednesday gave two interviews. One, to The New York Times, which was abhorrent. The second, to the progressive news magazine, The American Prospect. It's the latter that's getting all the attention, so much attention, it crashed the magazine's servers.\n\nBut why? Bannon's job reportedly is on thin ice. The violence in Charlottesville has turned up the heat on the neo-Nazi, white nationalist wing of the Trump White House, and in Tuesday's disastrous press event the president refused to say if Bannon's job was safe.\n\n\"We'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon,\" Trump told reporters.\n\nSo what happened Wednesday? How damaging was Bannon's interview with The American Prospect?\n\nHere's what a Bannon colleague in the White House told Axios.\n\n\"Since Steve apparently enjoys casually undermining U.S. national security, I'll put this in terms he'll understand: This is DEFCON 1-level bad.\"\n\nHere's what has Americans stunned:\n\nContrary to Trump's threat of fire and fury, Bannon said: \"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it. Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that ten million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nSo Bannon feels totally comfortable undermining U.S. foreign policy and national security. He gave away America's leverage. If you think it wasn't intentional, guess again.\n\n\"I was a little stunned to get an email from Bannon's assistant midday Tuesday, just as all hell was breaking loose once again about Charlottesville, saying that Bannon wished to meet with me,\" The American Prospect's Robert Kuttner reported.\n\nIn other words, Bannon heard Trump's refusal to offer him support, and has decided to go out in a blaze of glory - whatever the cost. Remember, Bannon is a founding board member of the far right wing website Breitbart and served as its publisher until Trump tapped him to run his flailing presidential campaign. And remember, Bannon is a strategist.\n\nThat was not the end of the interview.\n\nBannon also said, \"We're at economic war with China,\" and if we don't get the upper hand in five or ten years we'll have lost.\n\nAll of this, frankly, sounds like giving aid and comfort to the enemy, but that's for others to decide.\n\nIf revealing the White House game plan and beliefs about China and North Korea weren't enough, Bannon also went after Trump's core base of white nationalists.\n\nI asked Bannon about the connection between his program of economic nationalism and the ugly white nationalism epitomized by the racist violence in Charlottesville and Trump's reluctance to condemn it. Bannon, after all, was the architect of the strategy of using Breitbart to heat up white nationalism and then rely on the radical right as Trump's base.\n\nHe dismissed the far right as irrelevant and sidestepped his own role in cultivating it: \"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more.\"\n\n\"The Democrats,\" he said, \"the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em. I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"\n\nThat echoes Bannon's remarks in the interview he gave to The New York Times, which are stunning:\n\nStephen K. Bannon, the president's chief strategist, said in an interview that if Democrats want to fight over Confederate monuments and attack Mr. Trump as a bigot, that was a fight the president would win.\n\n\"President Trump, by asking, 'Where does this all end' -- Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln -- connects with the American people about their history, culture and traditions,\" he said.\n\n\"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" Mr. Bannon added. \"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. I can't get enough of it.\"\n\nBannon, Axios notes, now says he didn't know he was giving an interview. Kuttner makes clear Bannon contacted him out of the blue, they have never spoken before, Bannon did not say it was off the record, and did not even mention it, and, most importantly, Bannon is a media {"timeCrawl": "16:45:00", "uri": "711002067", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:09:00Z", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "source": {"title": "St. Louis Post-Dispatch", "uri": "stltoday.com", "id": "1117"}, "url": "http://www.stltoday.com/news/national/trump-aide-no-military-solution-in-north-korea/article_3dd3daec-5957-56ec-88c5-2e36c11f21c9.html", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) -- Contradicting a boss already under pressure to fire him, President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon says there's no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions. Just last week, Trump pledged to answer North Korean aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online Wednesday, Bannon tells the liberal publication that the U.S. is losing the economic race against China and talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nAsked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence, Bannon dismisses them as \"losers,\" ''a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nA White House spokeswoman said \"Bannon's comments stand on their own.\"\n\nIn a separate interview with the DailyMail.com, Bannon said his comments to The American Prospect \"drew fire away from\" Trump and that he successfully \"changed the (media) narrative\" around Trump with the earlier interview.\n\nBannon, one of the most contentious members of Trump's inner circle, is again facing an uncertain future in the White House, a situation that could be further complicated by his decision to give the initial interview.\n\nTrump passed up an opportunity this week to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon, who was a key campaign adviser during the general election and has become a forceful presence in a divided White House. But the former leader of the conservative Breitbart News has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump finds himself increasingly isolated, except among his core supporters, for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault in Charlottesville.\n\nOthers believe Bannon is behind a campaign conservative groups and the Breitbart website are waging against national security adviser H.R. McMaster, arguing he is insufficiently supportive of Israel and soft on Iran. Trump recently issued a rare public statement of support for McMaster.\n\nBannon's comments on North Korea, which contradict Trump's tough approach, could add to pressure on the president to fire him. Bannon has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump, who is irked by perceptions that Bannon was the mastermind of Trump's winning campaign and that he guides policy in the White House.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted early Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance on China trade -- without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented U.S. trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said Thursday that both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked at a regular news briefing about Bannon's comments, Hua said \"there is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon muses about getting rid of administration officials who disagree with his stance on China and North Korea and replacing them with \"hawks.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy,\" Bannon says.\n\nOne official Bannon mentioned by name is Susan Thornton, currently America's top diplomat for Asia.\n\nOn Thursday, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson signaled support for his senior adviser. After greeting Japan's defense chief and top diplomat at the State Department, Tillerson pointedly shook Thornton's hand in front of the cameras as their meeting began.\n\n-- -- --\n\nAssociated Press writer Matthew Pennington in Washington contributed to this report.\n\n-- -- --\n\nFollow Darlene Superville on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/dsupervilleap", "id": "9736180", "details": {}, "date": He also talks about purging his rivals from the Defense and State departments.\n\nBannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump tweeted earlier yesterday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the US territory of Guam.\n\nBannon also outlined his push for the US to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Kim, as Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Trump also has lamented US trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon says.\n\n\"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said yesterday both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked about Bannon's comments, Hua said at a regular new briefing, \"There is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nHua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-US relations.\"\n\nBannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. The former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Bannon has drawn fire from some of Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe president is under renewed pressure to fire Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Trump.(AP)\n\nEarlier this week, the President passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Bannon. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Trump faces mounting criticism for insisting that white supremacist groups and those who opposed them were both at fault for deadly violence last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.", "id": "9682718", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", {"timeCrawl": "04:22:00", "uri": "710672928", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T04:22:00Z", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "source": {"title": "TribLIVE", "uri": "triblive.com", "id": "1994"}, "url": "http://triblive.com/politics/politicalheadlines/12629823-74/bannon-says-he-fights-colleagues-daily-for-tough-china-policy", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "WASHINGTON -- White House chief strategist Steve Bannon took public his long-simmering feud with some of President Trump's top economic advisers, saying in an interview with The American Prospect that he battles them often, especially over his determination to take a tougher position on China.\n\n\"That's a fight I fight every day here,\" Bannon is quoted as saying in the interview published Wednesday. He pointed to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn, both alumni of Goldman Sachs Group Inc. who are pushing for a softer stance on trade with China. \"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying.\"\n\nThe interview was conducted Tuesday by the magazine's co-editor Robert Kuttner, who said Bannon told him he reached out because he agreed with Kuttner's past writings on China. Bannon rarely speaks with reporters on the record, let alone a liberal-leaning magazine.\n\nThe interview with Bannon comes as the White House has struggled to respond to Saturday's violent racial protests in Charlottesville, Va., and as some aides -- including Cohn -- have objected in private to Trump's restrained denunciations of white supremacists. Bannon approved of the president's approach, officials in the administration who asked not to be identified have said.\n\nBannon, who also once worked at Goldman Sachs, did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the interview.\n\nIn the interview Bannon said his rivals in the administration are \"wetting themselves\" as he works to undermine their influence with the president and he bragged about working to get some of them ousted. There has been speculation in recent days that Bannon could be in danger of losing his job, though Trump spoke in supportive terms about ahim at Tuesday's news conference.\n\nBannon said he favors pushing back against Chinese economic expansion, arguing only one country will emerge as a leader from what he described as an \"economic war.\"\n\n\"To me, the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" he said.\n\nHe advocated for the United States to file a complaint under Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act -- which allows for sanctions against countries that violate trade agreements or engage in unfair trade practices -- as well as follow-up complaints against steel and aluminum dumping, Kuttner wrote.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" Bannon said.\n\nBannon also dismissed speculation that the U.S might consider using military action against North Korea to get the regime there to abandon its intercontinental ballistic missile and nuclear weapon programs. Trump recently vowed to deliver \"fire and fury\" onto North Korea.\n\n\"There's no military solution, forget it,\" Bannon said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nBannon also was dismissive in the interview of the so called far-right that he helped organize and inflame when he led Breitbart News and during Trump's 2016 campaign.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he said. \"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nStill, Bannon said he's fine with the issue of race taking over the national conversation. \"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em,\" he is quoted as saying. \"I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Reuters cited three White House officials earlier Wednesday who said Bannon could be demoted by Trump, who they described as \"nervous\" about the blowback from punishing Bannon.\n\n\"The president obviously is very nervous and afraid of firing him,\" a source told
