{"timeCrawl": "04:24:00", "uri": "710673674", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T04:24:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"title": "Daily Nation", "uri": "nation.co.ke", "id": "1306"}, "url": "http://www.nation.co.ke/news/world/US-China-economic-war/1068-4060414-4bval8z/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Bannon described his fight within the administration to take a harder line against China's trade practices.\n\nWhite House strategist Steve Bannon argued forcefully in an interview published Wednesday that the United States is in an \"economic war\" with China, and the confrontation with nuclear-armed North Korea is just \"a sideshow.\"\n\n\"To me the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that,\" he said in the interview with the American Prospect, a left-leaning website.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, ten years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" he said.\n\nBannon, an economic nationalist and former CEO of the extreme-right Breitbart news website, is reported to be on shaky ground with President Donald Trump, who gave him only a tepid endorsement this week.\n\nBut in a frank, freewheeling telephone interview with American Prospect editor Robert Kuttner, Bannon talked about the infighting in the White House, now engulfed in a storm over Trump's defensive response to deadly violence at a white supremacist rally in Virginia.\n\nCOLLECTION OF CLOWNS\n\nFar from defending Trump, Bannon spoke with disdain about the white nationalist movement he helped cultivate as a former head of Breitbart.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nBannon also was dismissive of Trump's vow to bring down \"fire and fury\" on North Korea if it continued to threaten the United States with missiles and nuclear weapons.\n\n\"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it,\" he said.\n\n\"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that ten million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nHARDER LINE\n\nAccording to Kuttner's account, Bannon described his fight within the administration to take a harder line against China's trade practices, and not fall into the trap of hoping China would play the role of honest broker in restraining North Korea.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" he said.\n\n\"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing.\"\n\n\"One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"\n\nOf his adversaries in the State Department and Defence who want to enlist China's help Bannon said \"they're wetting themselves.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy. Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"", "id": "9609486", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "US in 'economic war' with China", "image": {"timeCrawl": "12:12:00", "uri": "710867024", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:12:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"title": "The Hindu", "uri": "thehindu.com", "id": "241"}, "url": "http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/bannon-says-no-military-solution-in-north-korea/article19509422.ece", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Despite Trump's talk of countering aggression with 'fire and fury.'\n\nUnited States President Donald Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon has said there is no military solution to the threat posed by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions, despite the President's recent pledge to answer further aggression with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nIn an interview with The American Prospect posted online on Wednesday, Mr. Bannon told the liberal publication that the US is losing the economic race against China. He also talked about purging his rivals from the Defence and State departments.\n\nMr. Bannon is also asked about the white supremacist movement, whose march on Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend led to deadly violence. He dismisses them as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element\" and \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nThe White House did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\n\"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it,\" Mr. Bannon says. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nMr. Trump tweeted earlier on Wednesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un \"made a very wise and well-reasoned decision\" by backing down after heightening fears of nuclear conflict in a series of combative threats, including against the US territory of Guam.\n\nMr. Bannon also outlined his push for the US to adopt a tougher stance on China trade, without waiting to see whether Beijing will help restrain Mr. Kim, as Mr. Trump has pressed China's leader to do. Mr. Trump also has lamented US trade deficits with China.\n\n\"The economic war with China is everything,\" Mr. Bannon says.\n\n\"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nA Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said on Wednesday both sides have benefited from trade.\n\nAsked about Mr. Bannon's comments, Ms. Hua said at a regular new briefing, \"There is no winner in a trade war. We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century.\"\n\nMs. Hua appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nMr. Bannon was a key general election campaign adviser and has been a forceful but contentious presence in a divided White House. A former leader of conservative Breitbart News, Mr. Bannon has drawn fire from some of Mr. Trump's closest advisers, including son-in-law Jared Kushner.\n\nThe President is under renewed pressure to fire Mr. Bannon, who has survived earlier rounds of having fallen out of favor with Mr. Trump.\n\nEarlier this week, the President passed up an opportunity to offer a public vote of confidence in Mr. Bannon. Mr. Trump said he's a \"good person\" and not a racist, adding that \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\nThe latest anti-Bannon campaign comes as Mr. Trump faces mounting criticism for {"timeCrawl": "07:24:00", "uri": "710739627", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:24:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"title": "TheJournal.ie", "uri": "thejournal.ie", "id": "979"}, "url": "http://www.thejournal.ie/steve-bannon-white-nationalists-3549816-Aug2017/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Steve Bannon Image: Carolyn Kaster/AP/Press Association Images Steve Bannon Image: Carolyn Kaster/AP/Press Association Images\n\nWHITE HOUSE STRATEGIST Steve Bannon has criticised the far-right in a surprise interview with American Prospect, a left-leaning political website.\n\nFar from defending US President Donald Trump, Bannon spoke with disdain about the white nationalist movement he helped cultivate as a former head of far-right website Breitbart.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nBannon, an economic nationalist and former CEO of Breitbart, is reported to be on shaky ground with Trump, who gave him only a tepid endorsement this week.\n\nIn a frank telephone interview with American Prospect editor Robert Kuttner, Bannon talked about the infighting in the White House - now engulfed in a storm over Trump's defensive response to deadly violence at a white supremacist rally in Virginia last weekend.\n\nNorth Korea\n\nBannon argued that the United States is in an \"economic war\" with China, and the confrontation with nuclear-armed North Korea is just \"a sideshow\".\n\n\"To me the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" he said.\n\nBannon was also dismissive of Trump's vow to bring down \"fire and fury\" on North Korea if it continued to threaten the US with missiles and nuclear weapons.\n\n\"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it,\" he said.\n\nUntil somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\n\nAccording to Kuttner's account, Bannon described his fight within the administration to take a harder line against China's trade practices, and not fall into the trap of hoping China would play the role of honest broker in restraining North Korea.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" he said. \"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing.\"\n\nOne of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\n\nBannon said his adversaries in the State Department and Defense Department who want to enlist China's help are \"wetting themselves\".\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy. Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"\n\n- \u00a9 AFP 2017\n\nRead: Thousands hold vigil for Charlottesville victim as Trump pays tribute to 'truly special young woman' Read: 'Violence' on the alt-left and Irish {"timeCrawl": "01:50:00", "uri": "710632048", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T01:50:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"title": "USA Today", "uri": "usatoday.com", "id": "335"}, "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2017/08/16/bannon-interview/574845001/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Skip in Skipx\n\nEmbed\n\nx\n\nShare\n\nCLOSE\n\nPresident Donald Trump says CEOs who have quit his White House council are 'leaving out of embarrassment.' His comments came Wednesday while answering questions from reporters in New York City. (Aug. 15) AP\n\nAmid reports of disgust and dismay among White House officials in the wake of President Trump's insistence that \"both sides\" bear the blame for the violence that broke out in Charlottesville, Va.., Saturday, there appears to be one member of the administration who couldn't be happier: White House Chief Strategist Steve Bannon.\n\nWhile others have decried Trump's remarks as a stain on the presidency, Bannon sees Tuesday's news conference as a \"defining moment\" in which Trump rejected the \"globalists\" and defended \"his people,\" according to a report from Axios.\n\nOne unnamed source told Axios that Bannon was \"proud\" that Trump \"stood up to the braying mob of reporters.\"\n\nAnd in a phone call to American Prospect co-founder and co-editor Robert Kuttner on Tuesday, Bannon seemed thrilled that Trump's opponents are talking so much about race.\n\nThe longer Democrats \"talk about identity politics, I got 'em,\" Bannon said. \"I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"\n\nBannon, the former executive chairman of Breitbart News who once called the site a \"platform for the alt-right,\" helped Trump form the nationalist message that cemented his base of support during the 2016 campaign.\n\nBut Bannon dismissed the white supremacists who demonstrated in Charlottesville as a \"bunch of clowns.\"\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers,\" Bannon told Kuttner. \"It's a fringe element, I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it.\"\n\nAnd Bannon did not seem concerned that Trump appeared to distance himself from him Tuesday. Rather, he said his rivals within the State and Defense departments are \"wetting themselves.\"\n\nBannon believes the U.S. is \"at economic war with China\" and many of those he views as adversaries wish to work with Beijing on trade and North Korea. He even called out some of those he wishes to see gone by name.\n\n\"I'm changing out people at East Asian Defense,\" Bannon said. \"I'm getting hawks in. I'm getting Susan Thornton out at State.\" Thorton is currently the acting head of East Asian and Pacific Affairs.\n\nBannon said he also is fighting Trump's national economic chair Gary Cohn and \"Goldman Sachs lobbying.\"\n\nBannon's strategy, according to Kuttner, \"is to battle the trade doves inside the administration while building an outside coalition of trade hawks that includes the left as well as right.\"\n\nKuttner believes Bannon reached out to him as part of this strategy. It was an effort to gain an ally from the left who shares some of his positions on China trade policy.\n\nKuttner said he found it \"puzzling\" that Bannon would \"assume that a possible convergence of views on China trade might somehow paper over the political and moral chasm on white nationalism.\"\n\n\"Either the reports of the threats to Bannon's job are grossly exaggerated and leaked by his rivals, or he has decided not to change his routine and to go down fighting,\" Kuttner concluded.\n\nRead more:\n\nTrump distances himself from strategist Steve Bannon in wake of Charlottesville violence\n\nSteve Bannon is hurting Trump's agenda, says ex-aide Anthony Scaramucci\n\nBannon learned to harness troll army from 'World of Warcraft'\n\nSteve Bannon had portrait of himself as Napoleon, report says\n\nA look a White House chief strategist Steve Bannon Fullscreen Bannon and Kushner listen during a Cabinet meeting in the White House on June 12, 2017. {"timeCrawl": "22:55:00", "uri": "711152634", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:55:00Z", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "source": {"title": "NBC News", "uri": "nbcnews.com", "id": "1630"}, "url": "http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/bannon-feels-secure-after-post-charlottesville-white-house-discord-n793561", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. -- People close to Steve Bannon tell NBC News he feels on safe ground amid White House infighting stemming from President Donald Trump's divisive response to the violence in Charlottesville.\n\nBannon, who has rarely given on-the-record interviews since assuming his position as Trump's chief White House strategist, reached out to speak with three news outlets in the past 48 hours, using those conversations to criticize colleagues, threaten to fire others and appearing to relish the ongoing national racial tensions.\n\nHis comments signal that Bannon, the former head of Breitbart News, is digging in for the long haul amid the turmoil and turnover that has roiled Trump's cohort of top advisers in recent weeks.\n\nBannon, in one interview with the American Prospect published late Wednesday, said his adversaries at the State and Defense Departments were \"wetting themselves\" and vowed he would soon be \"changing out people\" including Susan Thornton, the acting head of East Asian and Pacific Affairs at the State Department.\n\nHe also suggested infighting among Trump's closest advisers remained rampant.\n\n\"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying,\" he said, name-dropping Trump's National Economic Council director.\n\nBannon, who as Trump's campaign chief who was widely credited with helping Trump cultivate support among the alt-right, also called that wing of the party \"losers,\" \"a fringe element,\" and a \"collection of clowns.\"\n\n\"I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he said, just days after Trump said \"two sides\" were to blame for the violence in Charlottesville.\n\nBannon, however, added that forcing Democrats to talk about race would ultimately benefit Trump's White House.\n\n\"If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats,\" he said.\n\nA White House official confirmed the accuracy of the quotes by Bannon in the \"American Prospect\" article but said Bannon intended to have a conversation about the writer's article on North Korea, rather than a full interview.\n\nIn an interview with The New York Times, published Wednesday, Bannon said that \"the race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" referring to the debates raging nationwide over Confederate monuments.\n\n\"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. I can't get enough of it,\" he said.\n\nHe also told the Daily Mail, in an article Thursday morning, that his earlier comments were designed to distract from Trump's own controversial comments about Charlottesville, explaining to the Daily Mail's website that his initial interview \"drew fire away from POTUS,\" and \"changed the [media] narrative.\"\n\nBannon's original comments, however, clearly ruffled feathers at the State Department.\n\nFollowing Bannon's attack on one of Rex Tillerson's most trusted career State Department employees, the secretary of state pointedly walked over to publicly shake Thornton's hand before sitting down to meet with Japanese officials on Thursday.\n\n\"The Secretary asked Susan Thornton to lead in a very important role and he continues to rely on her to lead the State Department's diplomacy in Asia,\" a State Department official said. \"We refer you to the White House for any additional questions.\"\n\nThough he has survived a number of these episodes in the past, Bannon's status within the White House has remained unclear in recent weeks.\n\nFollowing the abrupt departures in July of Sean Spicer, Reince Priebus and Anthony Scaramucci, sources inside and outside the White House indicated Bannon's future seemed tenuous.\n\nAfter Trump's explosive response this week to the violence in Charlottesville, multiple members of his Manufacturing Council quit, too, before the president disbanded it as well as another key economic council.\n\nAt a Tuesday press conference where he doubled down on his Charlottesville remarks, Trump offered ambiguous words about Bannon when asked about his adviser's future in the West Wing.\n\n\"We'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon,\" he said.\n\nIt sounded ominous -- but Bannon appeared unconcerned.\n\nTwo sources close to him told NBC News this week he seemed confident he'll survive this latest round of bruising headlines questioning his political future with the president.\n\n\"He should go,\" said King, who accused Bannon of \"exploiting a racial issue\" and \"undercutting\" Trump and Tillerson. \"I think it's important for the president to fire Steve Bannon,\" he said.\n\nIn the past, Bannon has expressed quiet certainty when his job was thought to be on the line.\n\nIn February, after a Time magazine cover story that dubbed Bannon \"The Great Manipulator\" irritated Trump, Bannon quietly hunkered down and avoided media attention.\n\nThen, in April, following his removal from the National Security Council, Bannon, instead of leaving, dug in against a storm of bad press suggesting he was on his way out.\n\nBy July, several White House advisers had told Politico that Bannon, once the chief architect of Trump's campaign and agenda, had put himself in a \"self-imposed exile\" to enhance his prospects for West Wing longevity.\n\nTrump for his part, had made his displeasure with Bannon known in April, hitting back at his strategist in a pair of interviews.\n\n\"You have to remember he was not involved in my campaign until very late,\" Trump told the New York Post, downplaying Bannon's role as chief architect of his campaign victory. \"I had already beaten all the senators and all the governors, and I didn't know Steve. I'm my own strategist and it wasn't like I was going to change strategies because I was facing crooked Hillary.\"\n\nTrump also slammed Bannon in an interview with The Wall Street Journal as \"a guy who works for me.\"\n\nFollowing those interviews, a source close to the president described Trump's comments as a \"warning shot,\" highlighting that the president \"doesn't say these things in haste.\"\n\nThis time, however, the White House refused to even hint at condemning Bannon's remarks.\n\nWhite House Deputy Press Secretary Lindsay Walter told NBC News on Thursday that \"Bannon's If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\n\nTrump has enlisted Chinese President Xi Jinping in the U.S. effort to curb North Korean leader Kim Jong Un from turning his country into the world's ninth full-fledged nuclear power. But at the same time, Trump has chafed at the U.S.'s chronic trade deficit with Beijing, $347 billion last year and accumulating at a similar pace this year. This week Trump directed U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer to investigate whether China is stealing U.S. intellectual property, even as Beijing said both countries would end up being losers in any ensuing trade war.\n\nPushes 'America first'\n\nThe combative Bannon said he has to battle other White House aides every day to advance his no-holds-barred \"America first\" trade views against Trump aides who tend to favor existing efforts that emphasize multi-national trading cooperation.\n\nBannon joined Trump's White House staff after leading the conservative Breitbart News operation, which he once described as \"the platform for the alt-right\" nationalistic views. But he has often clashed inside the White House with aides with more moderate views, including Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon dismissed the importance in the U.S. of the politically far right.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalisn - it's losers,\" Bannon said. \"It's a fringe element. {"timeCrawl": "12:26:00", "uri": "710873398", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:26:00Z", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "source": {"title": "yahoo.com", "uri": "yahoo.com", "id": "228"}, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/steve-bannon-calls-white-nationalists-034252479.html", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "White House chief strategist Steve Bannon branded the white nationalists who rallied in Charlottesville as \"clowns\" on Wednesday, in a phone conversation likened to Anthony Scaramucci's infamous interview with the New Yorker.\n\nIn a wide-ranging, unsolicited interview with small left-leaning magazine The American Prospect, the former CEO of right-wing Breitbart News website argued the US was in an \"economic war\" with China, dismissed Donald Trump's vow to bring down \"fire and fury\" on North Korea, and talked of daily \"fighting\" within the government.\n\nMr Bannon, an economic nationalist, is reported to be on shaky ground with Mr Trump, who gave him only a tepid endorsement this week.\n\nThe frank, freewheeling telephone interview drew comparisons with the one Mr Scaramucci, the former White House communications director, gave to the New Yorker shortly before he was fired.\n\n\"This isn't as profane as Scaramucci but otherwise it's the same transgression. If he's not fired, he's bulletproof,\" Washington Post contributor Daniel Drezner tweeted.\n\nDo we think Bannon pulled a Scaramucci (i.e. accidentally blurted stuff not knowing rules) or was this deliberate? https://t.co/9TJDZocbBx -- Jeet Heer (@HeerJeet)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\n\"Just read the Bannon interview with the Prospect. It's truly extraordinary. His version of Scaramucci's call to Lizza,\" Axios reporter Jonathan Swan said.\n\nLike Mr Scaramucci, Mr Bannon reportedly did not realise the conversation was on the record. \"Apparently Bannon never thought that the journalist might take his (very newsworthy) comments and turn them into a story,\" Swan reported.\n\nProspect said that Bannon had never specified that the interview was off the record. Mr Bannon has yet to comment on the report.\n\nDuring the interview, the senior White House adviser talked about the storm over Mr Trump's defensive response to deadly violence at a white supremacist rally in Virginia at the weekend.\n\nFar from defending the president, Mr Bannon spoke with disdain about the white nationalist movement he helped cultivate as a former head of Breitbart.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism - it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nHe also said the administration's focus should be on China.\n\n\"To me the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that,\" he said.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, ten years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" he said.\n\nMr Bannon was dismissive of Mr Trump's vow to bring down \"fire and fury\" on North Korea if it continued to threaten the United States with missiles and nuclear weapons.\n\n\"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it,\" he said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that ten million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nAccording to the interview, Mr Bannon described his fight within the administration to take a harder line against China's trade practices, and not fall into the trap of hoping China would play the role of honest broker in restraining North Korea.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" he said. \"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing.\n\nIn his own words | Steve Bannon\n\n\"One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"\n\nOf his adversaries in the State Department, Treasury and Defence who want to enlist China's help, Mr Bannon said \"they're wetting themselves\" - and named Mr Trump's chief economic advisor Gary Cohn as one of his foes.\n\n\"That's a fight I fight every day here,\" he said. \"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying.\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy. Don't get me wrong. It's like, every day.\"", "id": "9685053", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "'If he's not fired, he's bulletproof': Steve Bannon calls white nationalists 'clowns' and discusses White {"timeCrawl": "09:19:00", "uri": "711354513", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T09:19:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"title": "North Korea Times ", "uri": "northkoreatimes.com", "id": "18203"}, "url": "http://www.northkoreatimes.com/news/254393029/white-house-aide-bannon-no-military-solution-in-north-korea", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Trump traded increasingly bellicose threats with North Korea in recent weeks in the aftermath of the reclusive communist country's two ballistic missile tests last month and its claim it could reach the U.S. mainland with an attack.\n\nBut Bannon, in an interview this week with The American Prospect magazine, minimized the possibility of a war erupting between the two countries.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" Bannon said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nFILE - , U.S. President Donald Trump, left, and Chinese President Xi Jinping arrive for a meeting on the sidelines of the G-20 Summit in Hamburg, Germany.\n\nEconomy top priority for US\n\nBannon said his biggest focus is for the United States, already the world's biggest economy, to win its trade war with China, the second biggest economy across the globe.\n\n\"To me, the economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon said. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" he said. \"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.'\n\nTrump has enlisted Chinese President Xi Jinping in the U.S. effort to curb North Korean leader Kim Jong Un from turning his country into the world's ninth full-fledged nuclear power. But at the same time, Trump has chafed at the U.S.'s chronic trade deficit with Beijing, $347 billion last year and accumulating at a similar pace this year. This week Trump directed U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer to investigate whether China is stealing U.S. intellectual property, even as Beijing said both countries would end up being losers in any ensuing trade war.\n\nWhite House Senior Advisers Steve Bannon, left, and Jared Kushner, listen as President Donald Trump speaks during a Cabinet meeting, June 12, 2017, in the Cabinet Room of the White House in Washington.\n\nPushes 'America first'\n\nThe combative Bannon said he has to battle other White House aides every day to advance his no-holds-barred \"America first\" trade views against Trump aides who tend to favor existing efforts that emphasize multi-national trading cooperation.\n\nBannon joined Trump's White House staff after leading the conservative Breitbart News operation, which he once described as \"the platform for the alt-right\" nationalistic views. But he has often clashed inside the White House with aides with more moderate views, including Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon dismissed the importance in the U.S. of the politically far right.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalisn - it's losers,\" Bannon said. \"It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more.\n\nTrump this week has drawn widespread attacks for saying that white supremacists and counter-protesters share the blame for the violence that erupted at a rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, killing one and injuring 19 others.\n\nSome Trump supporters have called for the president to fire Bannon. Whether Trump still values Bannon's advice is uncertain.\n\nAt a news conference earlier this week, Trump passed up a chance to offer Bannon a public vote of confidence, saying he's a \"good person\" {"timeCrawl": "17:50:00", "uri": "711031962", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T17:50:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"title": "Common Dreams", "uri": "commondreams.org", "id": "2370"}, "url": "https://www.commondreams.org/news/2017/08/16/defcon-1-level-bad-uproar-after-steve-bannon-gets-loose-lefty-magazine", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "In the wake of a site-crashing interview with the founder and editor of The American Prospect -- in which he talked about administration in-fighting, tensions with North Korea, looming economic war with China, and his high hopes for Democrat's focus on identity politics -- top Trump advisor Steve Bannon, according to responses gathered by Axios, is possibly in pretty deep(er) shit just about now with his White House colleagues.\n\nOne person, described by Axios' Jonathan Swan as \"not an enemy of [Bannon's],\" indicated the consquences of the interview could be severe.\n\n\"Since Steve apparently enjoys casually undermining U.S. national security,\" the White House staff member reportedly said, \"I'll put this in terms he'll understand: This is DEFCON 1-level bad.\"\n\nSteve Bannon's colleagues can't believe what they're reading tonight -- and here's the twist: neither can Bannon. https://t.co/SRyxJDv5Bc\n\n-- Jonathan Swan (@jonathanvswan) August 17, 2017\n\nTo begin with, it seemed a strange choice for Bannon to call the Prospect's Robert Kuttner, who confessed he was a \"little stunned\" to receive a message from Bannon's assistant that the former head of the right-wing Breitbart news outlet -- now one of Trump's most contentious and controversial top aides -- would be calling him to bounce around ideas.\n\nWhile some suggested Bannon might be acting the master strategist and somehow making a \"play\" with his call to Kuttner, Swan argued emphatically his belief this was not the case. \"You might read some takes tomorrow saying Bannon is playing 5D chess & this was part of a devious strategy,\" he tweeted. \"Those takes will be wrong.\"\n\nKuttner appeared on CNN Wednesday evening and said that his talk with Bannon revealed to him the man's \"hubris\" and \"arrogance\":\n\nAccording to Kuttner, who also writes in the article that Bannon never once brought up the idea that the conversation would be \"off the record,\" the motivation for the call was Kuttner's recent column on the subject of U.S. and North Korean tensions and the political and economic implications with China they entail. The argument of the article, entitled U.S. vs. North Korea: The Winner? China, had impressed Bannon. \"You absolutely nailed it,\" Bannon said.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Bannon continued. \"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"\n\nKuttner goes on to relate Bannon's description of \"his battle inside the administration to take a harder line on China trade, and not to fall into a trap of wishful thinking in which complaints against China's trade practices now had to take a backseat to the hope that China, as honest broker, would help restrain [North Korea's Kim Jong-un].\"\n\n\"To me,\" Bannon confessed, \"the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that.\"\n\nKuttner explained how Bannon's vision of the necessary Trump strategy will be to file \"a complaint under Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act against Chinese coercion of technology transfers from American corporations\" and that official objections to steel and aluminum dumping would follow. \"We're going to run the tables on these guys,\" Bannon explained. \"We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us.\"\n\nRemarking on internal tensions, Bannon said his rivals in the White House and elsewhere in government \"were wetting themselves\" over North Korean tensions, but he assured Kuttner that opponents of his plan to target China economically were actively being marginalized.\n\nBannon told Kuttner that Trump wants to proceed, calling it his \"default position,\" but that \"trade doves\" inside the White House were stalling the effort. In fact, the reaching out to Kuttner becomes central to the story at this point, as Bannon apparently perceives potential allies in left-wing critics of the trade policies preferred by corporate elites -- the same kind of people who Bannon derisively terms \"globalists.\" Kuttner dismissed that idea as naive, calling it a \"puzzling\" leap to think \"possible convergence of views on China trade might somehow paper over the political and moral chasm\" of the white nationalism Bannon represents and has championed.\n\nOf the white supremacists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia over the weekend, Bannon dismissed any responsibility he had for cultivating or making space for such movements and dismissed the participants as \"losers,\" \"a fringe element,\" and \"a collection of clowns.\" On the other hand, and according to separate reporting by Swan Wednesday night, Bannon is among those in the White House standing in approval of Trump's performance at Tuesday press conference, seeing it \"not as the lowest point in his presidency, but as a 'defining moment,' where Trump decided to fully abandon the 'globalists' and side with 'his people.'\"\n\nBut Bannon in his remarks to Kuttner also seemingly played his hand on the Democratic Party's response to the rise of Trump's brand of politics built around xenophobia, discrimination, and attacks on political correctness. \"The longer [the Democrats] talk about identity politics, I got 'em,\" Bannon said. \"I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"\n\nThe next step for Bannon and Kuttner's relationship? Kuttner said he received an invitation to come to the White House after Labor Day to discuss these issues further.\n\nIf, of course, as Kuttner quipped, Bannon's \"still there.\"", "id": "9747452", Bannon's rivals inside the White House and some of the President's outside advisers, including reportedly the conservative media mogul Rupert Murdoch, have urged the President to fire Bannon -- and the President on Tuesday declined to publicly offer Bannon any assurances on his fate. Bannon and the White House did not immediately respond to CNN's requests for comment.Read More\"We're at economic war with China,\" Bannon told the Prospect. \"One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years, and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"Bannon added that \"the economic war with China is everything,\" arguing the US needs to be \"maniacally focused on that.\"\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" Bannon said.The President's chief strategist, who has taken on an expansive portfolio from trade issues to the US's foreign wars and US manufacturing, also laid out his plans for the Trump administration to take a harder line against China on trade, explaining that the President's memorandum Monday that lays the groundwork for an investigation of Chinese trade practices is just a first step.\"We're going to run the tables on these guys,\" Bannon promised in the interview, explaining that the administration also plans to lodge trade complaints against China over steel and aluminum dumping.But Bannon also described his work to push this hardline trade agenda as a daily struggle that pits him against other top advisers to the President, including the National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn.\"That's a fight I fight every day here,\" Bannon said. \"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying.\"Bannon also accused his rivals inside the administration who have urged restraint on trade of \"wetting themselves\" over the issue.He went on to articulate how he is reshuffling the US's foreign policy apparatus, explaining that he is seeking the ouster of the Acting Assistant Secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs at the State Department and \"getting hawks in.\"The comments about his colleagues could place Bannon in a more precarious position inside the White House, whose staff is now being led by retired Gen. {"timeCrawl": "20:13:00", "uri": "711093720", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:13:00Z", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "source": {"title": "Vanity Fair", "uri": "vanityfair.com", "id": "2690"}, "url": "https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/08/steve-bannon-american-prospect-interview", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Is the populist-nationalist adviser playing 3-D chess, or flipping over the board?\n\nWith rumors of his imminent ouster percolating in the press, Steve Bannon, the embattled chief strategist and resident \"alt-right\" ideologue of Donald Trump's White House, placed a call to an unlikely outlet to vent: The American Prospect, a liberal-progressive magazine that has been highly critical of Trump. \"Needless to say, I was a little stunned to get an e-mail from Bannon's assistant midday Tuesday, just as all hell was breaking loose once again about Charlottesville, saying that Bannon wished to meet with me,\" wrote Robert Kuttner, who had just written a column about Trump's nuclear brinkmanship with North Korea's Kim Jong-un. \"Far from dressing me down for comparing Trump to Kim, he began, 'It's a great honor to finally track you down. I've followed your writing for years, and I think you and I are in the same boat when it comes to China. You absolutely nailed it.' \"\n\nThe story gets stranger from there: Bannon told Kuttner that he was champing for a trade war with China, which he believed would benefit from a nuclear standoff between North Korea and the U.S., and hoped that he could persuade left-wing activists to come on board. He undermined the administration's foreign policy strategy by saying that \"there's no military solution\" to the North Korean crisis where \"10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons.\" And he described in candid terms his clashes with colleagues (\"They're wetting themselves,\" he said) over what he sees as an existential economic battle with China. \"That's a fight I fight every day here,\" he said. \"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying.\"\n\nHe notably disavowed the same racists and anti-Semites who had flocked to the news organization he used to run, Breitbart, which he had once described as a \"platform for the alt-right.\" \"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he told Kuttner. \"These guys are a collection of clowns.\" He also expressed the hope that the Democrats would continue to talk about race, a hot topic after a recent white supremacist rally in Charlottesville turned deadly. \"The longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em. I want them to talk about racism every day,\" said Bannon, who himself said that he disavowed the white supremacists. \"If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"\n\nThe bizarre interview immediately recalled a similarly free-wheeling, if more vulgar, interview that Anthony Scaramucci gave to The New Yorker, hastening the end of his brief, 10-day tenure as White House communications director. But whereas Scaramucci, a political neophyte, could perhaps be forgiven for his miscalculation, Bannon's call confused even the Prospect. \"The question of whether the phone call was on or off the record never came up,\" wrote Kuttner, wondering why Bannon would forget such a crucial thing. \"He's probably the most media-savvy person in America.\" Axios's Jonathan Swan reported that Bannon claims he thought his comments were off-the-record, but the White House, which already believes the former Breitbart chairman was leaking damaging information about his colleagues to the press, is clearly not buying them. A White House adviser normally on collegial terms with Bannon told Swan: \"Since Steve apparently enjoys casually undermining U.S. national security, I'll put this in terms he'll understand: This is DEFCON 1-level bad.\"\n\nThe press and Bannon's acolytes, who pore over covert photos of his office whiteboard like screenshots from Game of Thrones trailers, had no idea what to make of this one. And in the absence of real information, the theorizing began: was this Bannon playing three-dimensional chess, or did he make a fatal error? \"I could see Bannon thinking he was talking to a China ally & being loose / excited,\" tweeted Swan, while others insisted that there was a method to Bannon's madness. \"Bannon did this interview to draw fire away from POTUS [and his Charlottesville comments] and it's working,\" tweeted Mike Cernovich, an Internet personality and Bannon sympathizer who drove a campaign to fire H.R. McMaster that Bannon got blamed for. Perhaps, speculated Yahoo's Daniel Roberts, this was Bannon sending a message to the White House and Trump:\n\nBannon later told the Daily Mail that the interview was a positive, that it \"drew fire away from POTUS\" and that he \"changed the [media] narrative.\" Swan responded on Twitter that the \"effect is possibly true, but Bannon is post rationalizing.\" He said Bannon had \"told friends he didn't know he was being interviewed [and] didn't expect to be quoted.\"\n\nThere may, however, be a simpler answer to those well-versed in Bannonology: that the anti-establishment, apocalyptic right-wing prophet simply does not care what happens to him, and is preparing to go out in a blaze of glory. He may be more powerful -- and better able to sow chaos -- from outside the White House, anyway.", "id": "9770098", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Steve Bannon Goes Full Mooch in And we have to be maniacally focused on that,\" he said in the interview with the American Prospect, a left-leaning website.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, ten years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" he said.\n\nBannon, an economic nationalist and former CEO of the extreme-right Breitbart news website, is reported to be on shaky ground with President Donald Trump, who gave him only a tepid endorsement this week.\n\nBut in a frank, freewheeling telephone interview with American Prospect editor Robert Kuttner, Bannon talked about the infighting in the White House, now engulfed in a storm over Trump's defensive response to deadly violence at a white supremacist rally in Virginia.\n\n- 'Collection of clowns' -\n\nFar from defending Trump, Bannon spoke with disdain about the white nationalist movement he helped cultivate as a former head of Breitbart.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nBannon also was dismissive of Trump's vow to bring down \"fire and fury\" on North Korea if it continued to threaten the United States with missiles and nuclear weapons.\n\n\"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it,\" he said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that ten million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nAccording to Kuttner's account, Bannon described his fight within the administration to take a harder line against China's trade practices, and not fall into the trap of hoping China would play the role of honest broker in restraining North Korea.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" he said. \"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing.\"\n\n\"One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"\n\nOf his adversaries in the State Department and Defense who want to enlist China's help Bannon said \"they're wetting themselves.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy. Don't get me wrong. Mr. Trump, in his remarks Tuesday blaming \"both sides\" for the violence in Charlottesville, also defended those who want to keep statutes memorializing the Confederacy. The Charlottesville event was originally billed as a protest against the removal of a statute of Confederate General Robert E. Lee from a public park.\n\n\"President Trump, by asking, 'Where does this all end' -- Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln -- connects with the American people about their history, culture and traditions,\" Bannon told the New York Times in an interview published Wednesday.\n\n\"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" Mr. Bannon added. \"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. I can't get enough of it.\"\n\nThe New York Times published Bannon's remarks the same day the American Prospect published a conversation with Bannon in which he said, \"we can crush the Democrats\" by focusing on \"economic nationalism.\" The White House claims Bannon believed the conversation was off the record.\n\n\"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em,\" Bannon told the American Prospect's Robert Kuttner. \"I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"\n\nSeveral high-placed sources inside and outside the White House have told CBS News that Bannon's position has never been in more jeopardy, CBS News Chief White House Correspondent Major Garrett reports.\n\nMr. Trump did nothing to ease those concerns about Bannon's future in his Tuesday remarks at Trump Tower, saying \"we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon.\"\n\n\"Well we'll see - look like, I like Mr. Bannon, he's a friend of mine, but Mr. Bannon came on very late, you know that,\" Mr. Trump said on Tuesday. \"I went through 17 senators, governors, and I won all the primaries. Mr. Bannon came on very much later than that, and I like him, he is a good man, he is not a racist, I can tell you that. He's a good person. He actually gets a very unfair press in that regard, but we'll see what happens with Mr. Bannon, but he's a good person, and I think the press treats him frankly very unfairly.\"\n\nBannon, who has And we have to be maniacally focused on that,\" he said in the interview with the American Prospect, a left-leaning website.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, ten years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" he said.\n\nRead: China warns of retaliation as Trump orders inquiry over trade ties\n\nBannon, an economic nationalist and former CEO of the extreme-right Breitbart news website, is reported to be on shaky ground with President Donald Trump, who gave him only a tepid endorsement this week.\n\nBut in a frank, freewheeling telephone interview with American Prospect editor Robert Kuttner, Bannon talked about the infighting in the White House, now engulfed in a storm over Trump's defensive response to deadly violence at a white supremacist rally in Virginia.\n\nFar from defending Trump, Bannon spoke with disdain about the white nationalist movement he helped cultivate as a former head of Breitbart.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"These guys are a collection of clowns.\" Bannon also was dismissive of Trump's vow to bring down \"fire and fury\" on North Korea if it continued to threaten the United States with missiles and nuclear weapons.\n\nRead: Trump to sign executive action to investigate China's trade practices\n\n\"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it,\" he said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that ten million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nAccording to Kuttner's account, Bannon described his fight within the administration to take a harder line against China's trade practices, and not fall into the trap of hoping China would play the role of honest broker in restraining North Korea.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" he said. \"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing.\"\n\nRead: Following pressure from US, China suspends North Korean iron, seafood imports\n\n\"One of us is going to be a hegemony in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"\n\nOf his adversaries in the State Department and Defence who want to enlist China's help Bannon said \"they're wetting themselves.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. {"timeCrawl": "06:34:00", "uri": "710715866", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T06:34:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"title": "The Straits Times", "uri": "straitstimes.com", "id": "611"}, "url": "http://www.straitstimes.com/world/united-states/stephen-bannon-contradicts-donald-trump-on-north-korea-and-far-right-groups", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "WASHINGTON (NYTIMES) - If President Donald Trump is considering whether to fire his chief strategist Stephen Bannon, as has been rumoured for weeks, Bannon just gave him several new reasons.\n\nIn an interview published on Wednesday (Aug 16) by a liberal journalist, Bannon contradicted the president's position on North Korea, bad-mouthed his colleagues in the administration, vowed to oust a female diplomat at the State Department and mocked Trump officials who fear the consequences of radically changing trade policy, saying they are \"wetting themselves.\"\n\nHe also described far-right groups as \"losers\" and \"clowns\", in the wake of the Charlottesville violence which Trump has blamed on the far-left and far-right.\n\nPeople close to Bannon said they believed the comments were part of an off-the-record conversation with Robert Kuttner of The American Prospect which he initiated.\n\nGet The Straits Times\n\nnewsletters in your inboxSign Up\n\nStill, they come as Bannon's adversaries are aggressively seeking his ouster from the White House because of his links to Breitbart News, his feuding with other White House aides and a suspicion that he is the source of leaks about internal chaos inside the West Wing.\n\nBannon's critics intensified their efforts after last weekend's racial unrest in Charlottesville, Virginia. Outraged over Trump's insistence that \"both sides\" were to blame for the violence that erupted during a white nationalist rally, leaving one woman dead, human rights activists demanded that the president fire so-called nationalists working in the West Wing. That group of hard-right populists in the White House is led by Bannon.\n\nOn Tuesday at Trump Tower in New York, Trump refused to guarantee Bannon's job security but defended him as \"not a racist\" and \"a friend.\" \"We'll see what happens with Mr Bannon,\" he said.\n\nIn the American Prospect article, titled \"Steve Bannon, Unrepentant,\" the president's strategist appears eager to lash out at his ideological rivals in the administration, bragging about his ability to defeat those who oppose a more aggressive posture toward China on trade policy.\n\n\"That's a fight I fight every day here,\" Bannon said. \"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying.\" Cohn is the director of the National Economic Council at the White House.\n\nHe also specifically named Susan Thornton, the acting director of the East Asian and Pacific Affairs division at the State Department, as someone he will dispatch.\n\n\"I'm changing out people at East Asian Defence; I'm getting hawks in,\" he said. \"I'm getting Susan Thornton out at State.\"\n\nJust a week after the president repeatedly threatened North Korea with military action in response to Pyongyang's nuclear missile program, Bannon mocked that position as nonsensical.\n\n\"There's no military solution, forget it,\" he said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nSpeaking on Tuesday, the same day that Trump was being assailed for his response to the Charlottesville protests, Bannon also dismissed the right-wing fringe as \"a collection of clowns.\"\n\nHe said the more liberals talk about \"identity politics,\" the easier it will be for Trump to defeat Democrats by focusing on economic nationalism.\n\nBannon told friends that he did not believe that his conversation was on the record. But he is a savvy media operator who rarely speaks without a clear understanding of the rules.\n\nKuttner said the issue of whether the call was on the record never came up.", "id": "9624912", {"timeCrawl": "03:36:00", "uri": "711229364", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T03:36:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "Republican American", "uri": "rep-am.com", "id": "5736"}, "url": "http://www.rep-am.com/news/national/2017/08/17/embattled-bannon-causes-storm-with-comments-to-liberal-writer-photo/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "WASHINGTON - The political world's latest feast is chewing over the stunningly candid comments of Stephen K. Bannon, President Donald Trump's polarizing and already embattled chief strategist, trashing associates and policies on North Korea and China - to a liberal writer, no less.\n\nThis dish isn't quite as wild as last month's phone call from Anthony Scaramucci to a New Yorker reporter. That one cost Scaramucci his job 10 days in for its combination of profanity, allusions to sex acts and backstabbing.\n\nStill, Bannon knew that history when he decided to unload his opinions to the liberal co-editor of the American Prospect, Robert Kuttner, whom he had never met.\n\nHe is either very confident in his job status or wants to get a few things off his chest before seeing the exit.\n\nBannon spoke openly about dispatching rivals in the administration, including in the Defense and State departments, who oppose his drive to confront China on trade. \"They're wetting themselves,\" he added.\n\nAnd he flatly contradicted Trump's strategy of tough talk in the face of North Korea's nuclear threat: \"There's no military solution, forget it.\"\n\n\"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, \" Bannon said. \"There's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nTrump has all but declared victory after Kim Jong Un tamped down his threats to attack Guam this week.\n\nBecause there's no solution to the North Korea problem, the White House should stop worrying about getting China's help on that issue and go hard against Chinese trade, Bannon said, pushing an issue that has been top priority for him.\n\nThe U.S. and China are in an \"economic war,\" Bannon said, adding that \"one of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years, and it's gonna be them if we go down this path\" of not confronting the Chinese over trade.\n\nSuch a sharp public contradiction on an important and volatile issue like Korea is startling for a top aide who expects to keep his job. Indeed, Trump failed to give Bannon a vote of confidence on Tuesday, saying \"we'll see\" when asked if Bannon would stay at the White House.\n\nThat lack of a strong endorsement added more intrigue to the American Prospect article.\n\nSo was he on the record? Some allies have suggested that Bannon did not think he was. But Kuttner seemed to anticipate those arguments, saying that the question never came up in their phone call. Like most reporters, he therefore considered it on the record.\n\nBannon is, after all, a former news chief.\n\n\"Steve Bannon is not exactly Bambi when it comes to dealing with the press,\" Kuttner {"timeCrawl": "19:38:00", "uri": "711077491", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T00:57:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "The Business Times", "uri": "businesstimes.com.sg", "id": "10474"}, "url": "http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/government-economy/us-in-economic-war-with-china-says-trump-strategist-bannon", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "[WASHINGTON] White House strategist Steve Bannon argued forcefully in an interview published Wednesday that the United States is in an \"economic war\" with China, and the confrontation with nuclear-armed North Korea is just \"a sideshow.\"\n\n\"To me the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that,\" he said in the interview with the American Prospect, a left-leaning website.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, ten years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" he said.\n\nMr Bannon, an economic nationalist and former CEO of the extreme-right Breitbart news website, is reported to be on shaky ground with President Donald Trump, who gave him only a tepid endorsement this week.\n\nBut in a frank, freewheeling telephone interview with American Prospect editor Robert Kuttner, Mr Bannon talked about the infighting in the White House, now engulfed in a storm over Mr Trump's defensive response to deadly violence at a white supremacist rally in Virginia.\n\n'COLLECTION OF CLOWNS'\n\nFar from defending Mr Trump, Mr Bannon spoke with disdain about the white nationalist movement he helped cultivate as a former head of Breitbart.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism - it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"These guys are a collection of clowns.\" Mr Bannon also was dismissive of Trump's vow to bring down \"fire and fury\" on North Korea if it continued to threaten the United States with missiles and nuclear weapons.\n\n\"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it,\" he said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that ten million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nAccording to Mr Kuttner's account, Mr Bannon described his fight within the administration to take a harder line against China's trade practices, and not fall into the trap of hoping China would play the role of honest broker in restraining North Korea.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" he said. \"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing.\" \"One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"\n\nOf his adversaries in the State Department and Defence who want to enlist China's help, Mr Bannon said \"they're wetting themselves.\" \"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy. Don't get me wrong. {"timeCrawl": "00:05:00", "uri": "710604765", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T00:05:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"title": "Clearfield Gant Daily", "uri": "gantdaily.com", "id": "537"}, "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/16/bannon-says-us-locked-in-economic-war-with-china-slams-white-house-colleagues/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Embattled White House chief strategist Steve Bannon declared in an interview published Wednesday that the US is at \"economic war with China,\" promised aggressive trade actions against Beijing and said he is \"fighting\" other top White House aides \"every day.\"\n\nBannon also dismisses the ratcheting up of tensions stemming from North Korea's nuclear and ballistic missile activity as \"just a sideshow\" and argues there is \"no military solution\" to the growing crisis, despite President Donald Trump's promises of \"fire and fury\" if North Korea continues to threaten or tries to target the US and its allies.\n\nThe startlingly candid comments, which were published Wednesday in an interview with The American Prospect, a progressive publication, come as Bannon's future inside the West Wing appears uncertain.\n\nBannon's rivals inside the White House and some of the President's outside advisers, including reportedly the conservative media mogul Rupert Murdoch, have urged the President to fire Bannon -- and the President on Tuesday declined to publicly offer Bannon any assurances on his fate.\n\nBannon and the White House did not immediately respond to CNN's requests for comment.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Bannon told the Prospect. \"One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years, and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"\n\nBannon added that \"the economic war with China is everything,\" arguing the US needs to be \"maniacally focused on that.\"\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" Bannon said.\n\nThe President's chief strategist, who has taken on an expansive portfolio from trade issues to the US's foreign wars and US manufacturing, also laid out his plans for the Trump administration to take a harder line against China on trade, explaining that the President's memorandum Monday that lays the groundwork for an investigation of Chinese trade practices is just a first step.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys,\" Bannon promised in the interview, explaining that the administration also plans to lodge trade complaints against China over steel and aluminum dumping.\n\nBut Bannon also described his work to push this hardline trade agenda as a daily struggle that pits him against other top advisers to the President, including the National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn.\n\n\"That's a fight I fight every day here,\" Bannon said. \"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying.\"\n\nBannon also accused his rivals inside the administration who have urged restraint on trade of \"wetting themselves\" over the issue.\n\nHe went on to articulate how he is reshuffling the US's foreign policy apparatus, explaining that he is seeking the ouster of the Acting Assistant Secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs at the State Department and \"getting hawks in.\"\n\nThe comments about his colleagues could place Bannon in a more precarious position inside the White House, whose staff is now being led by retired Gen. John Kelly.\n\nBannon's comments come just two weeks after White House communications director Anthony Scaramucci was fired after he badmouthed colleagues in vulgar terms in a conversation with The {"timeCrawl": "08:11:00", "uri": "710759090", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:11:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"title": "NBC News", "uri": "nbcnews.com", "id": "1630"}, "url": "http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/steve-bannon-says-u-s-economic-war-china-n793406", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "The United States is in an economic war with China, U.S President Donald Trump's chief political strategist has said, warning Washington is losing the fight but is about to hit China hard over unfair trade practices.\n\nIn an wide-ranging interview with prospect.org published Wednesday, Steve Bannon also weighed in on worsening tensions between the U.S. and North Korea, and the furor caused by white nationalist marches in Charlottesville, Virginia, over the weekend.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" said Bannon in the interview published in Wednesday.\n\n\"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon said the United States would use Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act against Chinese coercion of technology transfers from U.S. corporations doing business in China and follow up with complaints against steel and aluminum dumping, according to prospect.org.\n\nOn Monday, Trump authorized an inquiry into China's alleged theft of intellectual property in the first direct trade measure by his administration against Beijing.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" said Bannon, who acknowledged he was battling trade doves within the U.S. administration.\n\nHe said there was no reason to go soft on China in order to get Beijing's support over North Korea because he believed China would do little more to rein in Pyongyang.\n\nBannon said he might consider a deal in which China got North Korea to freeze its nuclear build-up with verifiable inspections and the United States removed its troops from the Korean peninsula, but such a deal seemed remote, prospect.org reported.\n\nIn contrast to Trump's threat of \"fire and fury\" against North Korea, Bannon said: \"There's no military solution, forget it.\"\n\n\"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about ...\"\n\nAsked about any connection between his economic nationalism and white nationalism in the United States, and in particular the racist violence in Charlottesville, Bannon said: \"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element.\"\n\n\"I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more. These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nHowever, Bannon, who formerly led the right-wing website Breitbart, said focusing on race would help the Republicans politically.\n\n\"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em. {"timeCrawl": "00:20:00", "uri": "710608390", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T00:20:00Z", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "source": {"title": "Washington Examiner", "uri": "washingtonexaminer.com", "id": "2955"}, "url": "http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/steve-bannon-economic-war-with-china-is-everything/article/2631787", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Steve Bannon says \"the economic war with China is everything\" and claims he's aiming to oust Trump administration officials who don't agree with his views.\n\n\"To me, the economic war with China is everything,\" Bannon said in a wide-ranging interview with the American Prospect, a liberal website, published Wednesday. \"And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, ten years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon, the White House chief strategist, suggested that China is not sincere in trying to help contest North Korea's nuclear program, so President Trump should not hesitate to be tougher with Beijing on trade issues.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Bannon said. \"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years, and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"\n\nOn Monday, the Trump administration announced trade action against China after previously delaying the move to get Beijing on board for sanctions against North Korea. China did approve the new sanctions in a unanimous United Nations Security Council vote earlier this month.\n\nSpecifically, Trump ordered the U.S. trade representative to investigate China's behavior on intellectual property rights. This is known as a Section 301 investigation, permitted under the 1974 Trade Act.\n\nFollowing this investigation, the Trump administration could impose tariffs on Chinese imports, rescind licenses, or take other action.\n\nBannon, in the American Prospect interview, seemed to say that an investigation of China is not necessary, and Trump should impose sanctions on Beijing immediately.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys,\" Bannon said of China. \"We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war, and they're crushing us.\"\n\nBannon said that he's trying to act against officials in the State, Defense, and Treasury Departments who don't agree with his views.\n\n\"Oh, they're wetting themselves,\" he said of his opponents in government. \"I'm changing out people at East Asian Defense; I'm getting hawks in. I'm getting Susan Thornton [acting head of East Asian and Pacific Affairs] out at State.\"\n\nThe Bannon interview comes as Trump is said to be considering firing him. Trump is reportedly resentful of Bannon's vivid media profile, and Bannon has been accused of leaking damaging information about other White House officials, including National Security Adviser H.R. One woman was killed and several of her fellow counter-protesters were injured when a car plowed through a crowd. In the days following the incident, President Donald Trump made a series of remarks -- some off the cuff -- that were strongly rebuked by politicians from both sides of the aisle.\n\nThe former editor of the far-right news website Breitbart is a controversial figure within the White House.\n\nA source close to Bannon told CNN he did not believe he was being interviewed when he spoke with the co-founder and co-editor of the American Prospect earlier this week.\n\n\"It was no interview,\" the source said.\n\nBannon and the White House did not immediately respond to CNN's requests for comment.\n\nEarlier this week, Rep. At one point, he even got candid about how he's going up against people like Gary Cohn:\n\nBut what about his internal adversaries, at the departments of State and Defense, who think the United States can enlist Beijing's aid on the North Korean standoff, and at Treasury and the National Economic Council who don't want to mess with the trading system?\n\n\"Oh, they're wetting themselves,\" he said, explaining that the Section 301 complaint, which was put on hold when the war of threats with North Korea broke out, was shelved only temporarily, and will be revived in three weeks. As for other cabinet departments, Bannon has big plans to marginalize their influence.\n\n\"I'm changing out people at East Asian Defense; I'm getting hawks in. I'm getting Susan Thornton [acting head of East Asian and Pacific Affairs] out at State.\"\n\nBut can Bannon really win that fight internally?\n\n\"That's a fight I fight every day here,\" he said. \"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and [National Economic Council chair] Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying.\"\n\nOn North Korea, Bannon also said, \"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it. Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that ten million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nHowever, with Charlottesville still a bit part of the national discussion, Bannon has been in the spotlight recently for other reasons. Bannon's association with the alt-right has led to renewed calls for him to be fired, especially after the events of Charlottesville. {"timeCrawl": "03:51:00", "uri": "710664980", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T03:51:00Z", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "source": {"title": "The Citizen", "uri": "citizen.co.za", "id": "4613"}, "url": "http://citizen.co.za/news/news-world/1615662/us-politics-china-nkorea-bannon/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "\"To me the economic war with China is everything. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nBannon also was dismissive of Trump's vow to bring down \"fire and fury\" on North Korea if it continued to threaten the United States with missiles and nuclear weapons.\n\n\"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it,\" he said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that ten million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nAccording to Kuttner's account, Bannon described his fight within the administration to take a harder line against China's trade practices, and not fall into the trap of hoping China would play the role of honest broker in restraining North Korea.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" he said. \"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing.\"\n\n\"One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. conflicting accounts.Bannon's remarks may have served to momentarily divert attention from the President's controversial response to the violence in Charlottesville, but his comments also offered damaging insight into the divisions inside the Trump administration and showed the chief strategist undercutting the President on the most significant national security issue facing the colleagues in vulgar terms to The New Yorker.Scaramucci later said he did not believe his conversation with The New Yorker reporter had been on the record, and later conceded he made a mistake.Robert
