{"timeCrawl": "20:13:00", "uri": "711094457", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:04:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "The Patriot Post", "uri": "patriotpost.us", "id": "1952"}, "url": "https://patriotpost.us/articles/50841", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Trump's chief strategist gives rare interview where he both disagrees with and praises his boss.\n\nOn Tuesday, Donald Trump's chief strategist, Steve Bannon, gave a phone interview with left-leaning magazine The American Prospect. The interview started with Bannon countering Trump's language on bringing \"fire and fury\" against Kim Jong Un's regime, asserting, \"There's no military solution [to the North Korean threat], forget it.\" Bannon continued, \"Until someone solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about. There's no military solution here. They got us.\"\n\nBut the conversation quickly pivoted to the hot-button issue of Charlottesville. Bannon commended Trump's handling of the press, and then went further in an effort to distance himself from his own Breitbart/alt-right associations. \"Ethno-nationalism,\" he said, \"it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much ... and we gotta help crush it.\" He continued, \"These guys [white supremacists] are a collection of clowns.\" Well, they're some of the same folks he declared Breitbart a \"platform\" for when he ran the news website.\n\nThis interview was an unusual decision for Bannon, who is wildly known to be quite hostile to the media and rarely grants interviews. In fact, it has been reported that Bannon was unaware that his statements were on the record. That suggestion is laughable, as Bannon is media savvy enough to know better -- especially less than a month after the Anthony Scaramucci blowup. In all likelihood this was an intentional play by Bannon, who has reportedly become increasingly isolated within the administration. Indeed, the Beltway rumor mill and 24/7 media talkingheads want us to believe his job is on the line. This may be plausible, due to news of much frustration among the White House staff over Trump's press conferences on Charlottesville, but it's hard to say. Bannon seems to be one of the few who was genuinely excited for Trump's response to the riot and called it a \"defining moment.\" He \"was proud of how [Trump] stood up to the braying mob of reporters.\"\n\nIt will be interesting to see if Trump sticks with Bannon, or if he chooses to cut him loose amidst all the mainstream media blow-back this week.", "id": "9770154", "details": {}, One woman was killed and several of her fellow counter-protesters were injured when a car plowed through a crowd. In the days following the incident, President Donald Trump made a series of remarks -- some off the cuff -- that were strongly rebuked by politicians from both sides of the aisle.\n\nThe former editor of the far-right news website Breitbart is a controversial figure within the White House.\n\nA source close to Bannon told CNN he did not believe he was being interviewed when he spoke with the co-founder and co-editor of the American Prospect earlier this week.\n\n\"It was no interview,\" the source said.\n\nBannon and the White House did not immediately respond to CNN's requests for comment.\n\nEarlier this week, Rep. Carlos Curbelo, R-Florida, named Bannon and Stephen Miller as individuals he thought were trying to accommodate the alt-right or white nationalists from within the West Wing, and advised the President to stop listening to them.\n\nBut Bannon's comments to the Prospect pushed back on that notion.\n\n\"It's a fringe element,\" Bannon told the magazine's co-founder Robert Kuttner about white nationalists within Trump's base. \"I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more.\"\n\nHe added: \"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nKuttner wrote that Bannon never asked for his remarks to be off the record.\n\n\"The question of whether the phone call was on or off the record never came up. {"timeCrawl": "04:22:00", "uri": "710672957", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T04:22:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"title": "Agence France Presse (AFP)", "uri": "afp.com", "id": "2391"}, "url": "https://www.afp.com/en/news/2266/us-economic-war-china-says-trump-strategist-bannon", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, ten years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" he said.\n\nBannon, an economic nationalist and former CEO of the extreme-right Breitbart news website, is reported to be on shaky ground with President Donald Trump, who gave him only a tepid endorsement this week.\n\nBut in a frank, freewheeling telephone interview with American Prospect editor Robert Kuttner, Bannon talked about the infighting in the White House, now engulfed in a storm over Trump's defensive response to deadly violence at a white supremacist rally in Virginia.\n\n- 'Collection of clowns' -\n\nFar from defending Trump, Bannon spoke with disdain about the white nationalist movement he helped cultivate as a former head of Breitbart.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nBannon also was dismissive of Trump's vow to bring down \"fire and fury\" on North Korea if it continued to threaten the United States with missiles and nuclear weapons.\n\n\"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it,\" he said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that ten million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nAccording to Kuttner's account, Bannon described his fight within the administration to take a harder line against China's trade practices, and not fall into the trap of hoping China would play the role of honest broker in restraining North Korea.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" he said. \"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing.\"\n\n\"One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"\n\nOf his adversaries in the State Department and Defense who want to enlist China's help Bannon said \"they're wetting themselves.\"\n\n\"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy. Don't get me wrong. {"timeCrawl": "05:19:00", "uri": "710690354", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:19:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"title": "Japan Today", "uri": "japantoday.com", "id": "18472"}, "url": "https://japantoday.com/category/world/refile-trump-adviser-bannon-says-u.s.-in-economic-war-with-china-media", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "The United States is in an economic war with China, U.S President Donald Trump's chief political strategist has said, warning Washington is losing the fight but is about to hit China hard over unfair trade practices.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Steve Bannon told U.S. news site prospect.org in an interview published in Wednesday.\n\n\"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon said the United States would use Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act against Chinese coercion of technology transfers from U.S. corporations doing business in China and follow up with complaints against steel and aluminium dumping, according to prospect.org.\n\nOn Monday, Trump authorised an inquiry into China's alleged theft of intellectual property in the first direct trade measure by his administration against Beijing.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" said Bannon, who acknowledged he was battling trade doves within the U.S. administration.\n\nHe said there was no reason to go soft on China in order to get Beijing's support over North Korea because he believed China would do little more to rein in Pyongyang.\n\nBannon said he might consider a deal in which China got North Korea to freeze its nuclear build-up with verifiable inspections and the United States removed its troops from the Korean peninsula, but such a deal seemed remote, prospect.org reported.\n\nIn contrast to Trump's threat of \"fire and fury\" against North Korea, Bannon said: \"There's no military solution, forget it.\"\n\n\"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about ...\"\n\nAsked about any connection between his economic nationalism and white nationalism in the United States, and in particular the racist violence in Charlottesville, Bannon said:\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element.\"\n\n\"I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more. These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nHowever, Bannon, who formerly led the right-wing website Breitbart, said focusing on race would help the Republicans politically.\n\n\"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em. I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"\n\n\u00a9 (c) Copyright Thomson Reuters 2017.", "id": "9615283", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "05:21:00", "uri": "710691310", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:21:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"title": "Reuters", "uri": "reuters.com", "id": "8"}, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-china-bannon-idUSKCN1AX0DE", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "(Reuters) - The United States is in an economic war with China, U.S President Donald Trump's chief political strategist has said, warning Washington is losing the fight but is about to hit China hard over unfair trade practices.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Steve Bannon told U.S. news site prospect.org in an interview published in Wednesday.\n\n\"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon said the United States would use Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act against Chinese coercion of technology transfers from U.S. corporations doing business in China and follow up with complaints against steel and aluminum dumping, according to prospect.org.\n\nOn Monday, Trump authorized an inquiry into China's alleged theft of intellectual property in the first direct trade measure by his administration against Beijing.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" said Bannon, who acknowledged he was battling trade doves within the U.S. administration.\n\nHe said there was no reason to go soft on China in order to get Beijing's support over North Korea because he believed China would do little more to rein in Pyongyang.\n\nBannon said he might consider a deal in which China got North Korea to freeze its nuclear build-up with verifiable inspections and the United States removed its troops from the Korean peninsula, but such a deal seemed remote, prospect.org reported.\n\nIn contrast to Trump's threat of \"fire and fury\" against North Korea, Bannon said: \"There's no military solution, forget it.\"\n\n\"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about ...\"\n\nAsked about any connection between his economic nationalism and white nationalism in the United States, and in particular the racist violence in Charlottesville, Bannon said: \"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element.\"\n\n\"I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more. These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nHowever, Bannon, who formerly led the right-wing website Breitbart, said focusing on race would help the Republicans politically.\n\n\"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em. I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"", "id": "9615642", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Trump adviser Bannon {"timeCrawl": "07:34:00", "uri": "710743005", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:34:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"title": "RTE.ie", "uri": "rte.ie", "id": "1151"}, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2017/0817/897990-us-china-trade/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "The United States is in an economic war with China, US President Donald Trump's chief political strategist has said, warning Washington is losing the fight but is about to hit China hard over unfair trade practices.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Steve Bannon told US news site prospect.org in an interview published yesterday.\n\n\"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nMr Bannon said the United States would use Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act against Chinese coercion of technology transfers from US corporations doing business in China and follow up with complaints against steel and aluminium dumping, according to prospect.org.\n\nOn Monday, Trump authorised an inquiry into China's alleged theft of intellectual property in the first direct trade measure by his administration against Beijing.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" said Mr Bannon, who acknowledged he was battling trade doves within the US administration.\n\nHe said there was no reason to go soft on China in order to get Beijing's support over North Korea because he believed China would do little more to rein in Pyongyang.\n\nMr Bannon said he might consider a deal in which China got North Korea to freeze its nuclear build-up with verifiable inspections and the United States removed its troops from the Korean peninsula, but such a deal seemed remote, prospect.org reported.\n\nIn contrast to Trump's threat of \"fire and fury\" against North Korea, Mr Bannon said: \"There's no military solution, forget it.\"\n\n\"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about ...\"\n\nAsked about any connection between his economic nationalism and white nationalism in the United States, and in particular the racist violence in Charlottesville, Bannon said: \"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element.\"\n\n\"I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path,\" he was quoted as saying. \"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\" Bannon said the United States would use Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act against Chinese coercion of technology transfers from US corporations doing business in China and follow up with complaints against steel and aluminium dumping, according to prospect.org. On Monday, Trump authorised an inquiry into China's alleged theft of intellectual property in the first direct trade measure by his administration against Beijing. \"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" said Bannon, who acknowledged he was battling trade doves within the US administration.\n\nHe said there was no reason to go soft on China in order to get Beijing's support over North Korea because he believed China would do little more to rein in Pyongyang.\n\nBannon said he might consider a deal in which China got North Korea to freeze its nuclear build-up with verifiable inspections and the United States removed its troops from the Korean peninsula, but such a deal seemed remote, prospect.org reported.\n\nWatch this also:\n\nIn contrast to Trump's threat of \"fire and fury\" against North Korea, Bannon said: \"There's no military solution, forget it.\" \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about ...\" Asked about any connection between his economic nationalism and white nationalism in the United States, and in particular the racist violence in Charlottesville, Bannon said: \"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. (Gage Skidmore/Flickr)\n\nChief White House adviser Steve Bannon on Thursday defended his controversial interview with the American Prospect, praising himself for \"[drawing] fire away from\" Donald Trump and \"[changing] the narrative\" around the president equating a white supremacist rally with counter-protestors who stood against racism and bigotry.\n\nBannon on Wednesday made headlines after he called the American Prospect's Robert Kuttner to talk about everything from ethno-nationalists to North Korea. In the aftermath of that interview, aides to the chief White House strategist told Axios Bannon -- who's been labeled a \"leaker\" by several current and former administration officials -- thought the call was off the record.\n\n\"This is DEFCON 1-level bad,\" one of Bannon's colleagues told Axios.\n\nNow, Bannon is reportedly thanking himself for that interview, telling the Daily Mail he \"drew fire away from POTUS\" and \"changed the [media] narrative\" from nonstop coverage of the president's Charlottesville response, albeit briefly.\n\nIn that interview with the American Prospect, Bannon appeared to undercut the White House position on North Korea, arguing \"there's no military solution\" to deal with the rogue nuclear power. He also called ehtno-nationalists \"losers,\" adding \"it's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it.\"\n\nBannon -- who was described as in \"high spritis\" during the call -- further insisted he's \"got\" Democrats as long as they talk about what he described as \"identity politics.\"\n\n\"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em,\" Bannon told the American Prospect. \"I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"\n\nBannon echoed that sentiment in a decidedly on-record interview with the New York Times, inviting the left to \"tear down more statues.\"\n\n\"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" Bannon told the Times. \"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. I can't get enough of it.\"\n\nIt's unclear how the American Prospect interview writ large is playing with Trump, but at least one administration praised Bannon for his criticism of Democrats and ethno-nationlists.\n\n\"The president doesn't like all the Democrats' focus on racism, and it's good that Steve mocked it as politically stupid,\" an aide told the Daily Mail. \"Plus, distance from I want them to talk about racism every day,' he boasted.\n\n'If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.'\n\nWhite House chief strategist Steve Bannon called a liberal magazine writer on Wednesday and dished to him about the North Korean standoff, an economic war in China and race politics\n\nAlong the way, he sought to distance himself from the white nationalists and other 'alt-right' denizens who have found an ideological bedfellow in Breitbart News, the website he led until last year.\n\n'Ethno-nationalism - it's losers,' he said. {"timeCrawl": "05:15:00", "uri": "710688978", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:15:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4798122/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Aug 17 (Reuters) - The United States is in an economic war with China, U.S President Donald Trump's chief political strategist has said, warning Washington is losing the fight but is about to hit China hard over unfair trade practices.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Steve Bannon told U.S. news site prospect.org in an interview published in Wednesday.\n\n\"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon said the United States would use Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act against Chinese coercion of technology transfers from U.S. corporations doing business in China and follow up with complaints against steel and aluminium dumping, according to prospect.org.\n\nOn Monday, Trump authorised an inquiry into China's alleged theft of intellectual property in the first direct trade measure by his administration against Beijing.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" said Bannon, who acknowledged he was battling trade doves within the U.S. administration.\n\nHe said there was no reason to go soft on China in order to get Beijing's support over North Korea because he believed China would do little more to rein in Pyongyang.\n\nBannon said he might consider a deal in which China got North Korea to freeze its nuclear build-up with verifiable inspections and the United States removed its troops from the Korean peninsula, but such a deal seemed remote, prospect.org reported.\n\nIn contrast to Trump's threat of \"fire and fury\" against North Korea, Bannon said: \"There\u00b4s no military solution, forget it.\"\n\n\"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don\u00b4t know what you\u00b4re talking about ...\"\n\nAsked about any connection between his economic nationalism and white nationalism in the United States, and in particular the racist violence in Charlottesville, Bannon said: \"Ethno-nationalism - it's losers. It's a fringe element.\"\n\n\"I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more. These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nHowever, Bannon, who formerly led the right-wing website Breitbart, said focusing on race would help the Republicans politically.\n\n\"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em. I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\" (Reporting by Michael Perry; Editing by Paul Tait)", "id": "9614810", "details": {}, (Representational Image) China tells Trump not to link trade to North KoreaUS plans to make arms deal worth of $1.42 billion with TaiwanUS open to work with China to resolve issues of importance -- North Korea, trade\n\nPresident Donald Trump's close aide Steve Bannon has advocated a tougher stance toward China asserting that the US is at economic war with it, prompting Beijing to warn that \"there is no winner in a trade war\".\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Chief White House Strategist Steve Bannon told The American Prospect.\n\nOf late media reports have said that Bannon is pushing for a strong policy against China. Many within the Trump Administration differ with him. \"To me the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, ten years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" Bannon said in response to a question.\n\nThe Chief White House Strategist said the United States would take a strong action against China. \"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" said Bannon who once headed the right-wing Breitbart News.\n\nCommenting on his remarks, Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying in Beijing warned that \"there is no winner in a trade war\" and appealed for dialogue. \"We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century,\" she said.\n\nIn his interview over phone, Bannon argued that there was no military solution to North Korean provocative behaviour. \"There's no military solution (to North Korea's nuclear threats), forget it. Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us,\" Bannon said.\n\nOn Monday, Trump signed an executive order asking the US Trade Representative for examination of Chinese policies, practices, and actions with regard to the forced transfers of US technology and the theft of its intellectual property. \"The theft of intellectual property by foreign countries costs our nation millions of jobs and billions and billions of dollars each and every year. For too long, this wealth has been drained from our country while Washington has done nothing,\" Trump said.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon said that he is getting hawks placed at key position. At the same time he acknowledged that he is getting opposition from various section. \"That's a fight I fight every day here,\" he said.\n\n\"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and [National Economic Council chair] Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying,\" he added. \"We gotta do this. The president's default position is to do it, but the apparatus is going crazy. Don't get me wrong. {"timeCrawl": "20:37:00", "uri": "711103523", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:37:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "TODAY", "uri": "todayonline.com", "id": "1197"}, "url": "http://www.todayonline.com/world/americas/us-engaged-economic-war-china-top-white-house-aide-bannon-argues", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "WASHINGTON -- White House strategist Steve Bannon argued forcefully in an interview published on Wednesday (US local time) that the United States is in an \"economic war\" with China.\n\n\"To me, the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that,\" he said in the interview with the left-leaning website American Prospect. He also contradicted the president's position on North Korea, bad-mouthed his colleagues in the administration and mocked Trump officials who fear the consequences of radically changing trade policy, saying they are \"wetting themselves\". Mr Bannon criticised the white nationalist movement during the interview as well.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it -- we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" he added. \"One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's going be them if we go down this path.\"\n\nPeople close to Mr Bannon said he believed the interview was part of an off-the-record conversation with Mr Robert Kuttner with The American Prospect that, according to the magazine, he initiated. Mr Kuttner said the issue of whether the call was on the record never came up.\n\nAsked about Mr Bannon's comments, Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying said at a regular news briefing that \"there is no winner in a trade war\".\n\n\"We hope the relevant people can refrain from dealing with a problem in the 21st century with a zero-sum mentality from the 19th or the 20th century,\" said Ms Hua, who also appealed for dialogue to \"preserve the sound and steady growth of China-US relations\".\n\nMr Bannon's comments came as Washington launches a probe into Beijing's theft of American technology and intellectual property in a move that could lead to steep tariffs on Chinese goods and a trade war.\n\nMr Bannon, an economic nationalist and former chief executive of the extreme-right Breitbart news website, is reported to be on shaky ground with President Donald Trump, who gave him only a tepid endorsement this week.\n\nBut, in the frank, freewheeling telephone interview with Mr Kuttner, Mr Bannon talked about the infighting in the White House, now engulfed in a storm over Mr Trump's defensive response to deadly violence at a white supremacist rally in Virginia.\n\nFar from defending Mr Trump, Mr Bannon spoke with disdain about the white nationalist movement he helped cultivate as a former Breitbart head. \"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we got to help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more,\" he was quoted as saying. \"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nMr Bannon also dismissed Mr Trump's vow to bring down \"fire and fury\" on North Korea if it continued to threaten the US with missiles and nuclear weapons. \"There's no military solution -- forget it,\" he said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about. There's no military solution here -- they got us.\"\n\nAsked about Mr Bannon's comments on North Korea, the top US military officer, General Joseph Dunford, told reporters in Beijing yesterday that Mr Trump has \"told us to develop credible viable military options and that's exactly what we're doing\".\n\nIn addition, Mr Bannon spoke to Mr Kuttner about his long-simmering feud with some of Mr Trump's top economic advisers, adding that he battles them often, especially over his determination to take a tougher position on China.\n\n\"That's a fight I fight every day here,\" Mr Bannon is quoted as saying in the interview about his feuds with other senior officials over China.\n\nHe pointed to fellow Goldman Sachs alumni, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and National Economic Council director Gary Cohn, who are pushing for a softer stance on trade with China.\n\n\"We're still fighting. There's Treasury and Gary Cohn and Goldman Sachs lobbying,\" Mr Bannon said.\n\nResponding to Mr Bannon's interview with the American Prospect, an article on The American Conservative website noted that he is either \"a genius, or he's reckless and crazy\".\n\n\"Or maybe he's both, but his recklessness outran his genius this one time. I can't see how he survives having talked so loosely to a journalist -- a liberal journalist at that -- about administration infighting and the White House's approach to North Korea and China,\" the article added. {"timeCrawl": "17:25:00", "uri": "711021408", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T17:21:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "Clearfield Gant Daily", "uri": "gantdaily.com", "id": "537"}, "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/17/bannons-interview-a-blunder-or-intentional-ploy/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "White House chief strategist Steve Bannon is privately offering shifting and conflicting explanations for the strikingly candid interview that could further imperil his already shaky standing inside the West Wing.\n\nSources close to Bannon first said the chief strategist did not know he was being interviewed when he spoke over the phone with Robert Kuttner, the co-editor of The American Prospect. But the same sources now say the chief strategist granted the interview as part of a ploy to distract from the criticism President Donald Trump has been facing over his response to the violence in Charlottesville sparked by a white supremacist rally.\n\n\"Bannon knew full well this would distract from criticism,\" a source familiar with Bannon's thinking said.\n\nA second source familiar with Bannon's thinking said the chief strategist was trying \"to divert attention from Charlottesville criticism\" by offering the controversial comments to the American Prospect reporter, knowing the comments would grip headlines.\n\nBannon has declined to comment and did not respond to CNN's inquiry asking about the conflicting accounts.\n\nBannon's remarks may have served to momentarily divert attention from the President's controversial response to the violence in Charlottesville, but his comments also offered damaging insight into the divisions inside the Trump administration and showed the chief strategist undercutting the President on the most significant national security issue facing the administration.\n\nWhile Trump promised to rain \"fire and fury\" on North Korea should the rogue regime continue to threaten or attempt to strike the US or its allies, Bannon dismissed North Korea as a \"sideshow\" to the larger economic conflicts between the US and China and argued there is \"no military solution\" to the crisis.\n\nThe remarkable comments were reminiscent of what got Bannon into hot water earlier this year, when a narrative began to set in that he was effectively running the White House.\n\nBannon also offered unprompted criticism of fellow advisers to the president, including National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn, whom Bannon placed among those he is fighting \"every day\" to push a harder line on international trade issues.\n\nThose comments in particular could land Bannon in trouble with the President and his recently-installed chief of staff John Kelly, who just two weeks earlier ousted White House communications director Anthony Scaramucci after he badmouthed colleagues in vulgar terms to The New Yorker.\n\nScaramucci later said he did not believe his conversation with The New Yorker reporter had been on the record, and later conceded he made a mistake.\n\nRobert Kuttner, the Prospect editor who interviewed Bannon on Tuesday, wrote in his article that \"the question of whether the phone call was on or off the record never came up.\"\n\n\"This is also puzzling, since Steve Bannon is not exactly Bambi when it comes to dealing with the press. He's probably the most media-savvy person in America,\" Kuttner wrote.\n\nBannon, the former Breitbart chief, is known for being particular media savvy and -- like other experienced Washington hands Hall (@samrhall) August 17, 2017\n\nBannon is already on thin ice with newly appointed chief of Staff John Kelly reportedly unhappy with the influence he wields in the White House. {"timeCrawl": "10:37:00", "uri": "710824682", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:37:00Z", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "source": {"title": "rawstory.com", "uri": "rawstory.com", "id": "5491"}, "url": "http://www.rawstory.com/2017/08/trump-adviser-steve-bannon-says-the-us-is-in-economic-war-with-china-media/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Trump administration chief strategist Steve Bannon (Screen cap).\n\nThe United States is in an economic war with China, U.S President Donald Trump's chief political strategist has said, warning Washington is losing the fight but is about to hit China hard over unfair trade practices.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Steve Bannon told U.S. news site prospect.org in an interview published in Wednesday.\n\n\"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nChinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying said she had seen the report, and reiterated the essence of the China-U.S. trade relationship is mutually beneficial.\n\n\"In reality, China and the United States' long term cooperation has brought about real benefits for both countries' peoples, any unbiased person will clearly see this fact,\" she told a daily news briefing in Beijing.\n\n\"We have also said before, a trade war has no future. A trade war does not serve the interests of any party, as fighting a trade war will not produce a winner. We hope that relevant parties can stop viewing issues of the 21st century with a 19th- or 20th-century mentality.\"\n\nBannon said the United States would use Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act against Chinese coercion of technology transfers from U.S. corporations doing business in China and follow up with complaints against steel and aluminum dumping, according to prospect.org.\n\nOn Monday, Trump authorized an inquiry into China's alleged theft of intellectual property in the first direct trade measure by his administration against Beijing.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" said Bannon, who acknowledged he was battling trade doves within the U.S. administration.\n\nHe said there was no reason to go soft on China in order to get Beijing's support over North Korea because he believed China would do little more to rein in Pyongyang.\n\nBannon said he might consider a deal in which China got North Korea to freeze its nuclear build-up with verifiable inspections and the United States removed its troops from the Korean peninsula, but such a deal seemed remote, prospect.org reported.\n\nIn contrast to Trump's threat of \"fire and fury\" against North Korea, Bannon said: \"There's no military solution, forget it.\"\n\n\"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about ...\"\n\nAsked about any connection between his economic nationalism and white nationalism in the United States, and in particular the racist violence in Charlottesville, Bannon said: \"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element.\"\n\n\"I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more. These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nHowever, Bannon, who formerly led the right-wing website Breitbart, said focusing on race would help the Republicans politically.\n\n\"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em. I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"\n\n(Reporting by Michael Perry; Additional reporting by Christian Shepherd in BEIJING; {"timeCrawl": "09:38:00", "uri": "710797268", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T09:38:00Z", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "source": {"title": "The Straits Times", "uri": "straitstimes.com", "id": "611"}, "url": "http://www.straitstimes.com/world/united-states/us-in-economic-war-with-china-says-trump-adviser-bannon", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "WASHINGTON (REUTERS) - The United States is in an economic war with China, US President Donald Trump's chief political strategist has said, warning Washington is losing the fight but is about to hit China hard over unfair trade practices.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Mr Stephen Bannon told US news website prospect.org in an interview published on Wednesday (Aug 16).\n\n\"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nGet The Straits Times\n\nnewsletters in your inboxSign Up\n\nMr Bannon said the United States would use Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act against Chinese coercion of technology transfers from US corporations doing business in China and follow up with complaints against steel and aluminium dumping, according to prospect.org.\n\nOn Monday, Mr Trump authorised an inquiry into China's alleged theft of intellectual property in the first direct trade measure by his administration against Beijing. \"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" said Mr Bannon, who acknowledged he was battling trade doves within the US administration.\n\nHe said there was no reason to go soft on China in order to get Beijing's support over North Korea because he believed China would do little more to rein in Pyongyang.\n\nMr Bannon said he might consider a deal in which China got North Korea to freeze its nuclear build-up with verifiable inspections, and the United States removed its troops from the Korean peninsula, but such a deal seemed remote, prospect.org reported.\n\nIn contrast to Mr Trump's threat of \"fire and fury\" against North Korea, Mr Bannon said: \"There's no military solution, forget it.\n\n\"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about...\"\n\nAsked about any connection between his economic nationalism and white nationalism in the US, and, in particular, the racist violence in Charlottesville, Mr Bannon said: \"Ethno-nationalism - it's losers. It's a fringe element.\n\n\"I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more. These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nHowever, Mr Bannon, who formerly led the right-wing website Breitbart, said focusing on race would help the Republicans politically.\n\n\"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em. I want them to talk about racism every day. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more ... These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nWhile talking about the far right, Bannon took the opportunity to slam Democrats' fondness for \"identity politics.\"\n\n\"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em,\" he said. \"I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon seemed to counter President Trump's incendiary comments about unleashing \"fire and fury\" on North Korea if it continues to threaten the U.S.\n\n\"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats]. Forget it,\" Bannon said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about. There's no military solution here. They got us.\"\n\nHe had harsh words for China, which he said is at war with the U.S. economically. He added that the U.S. is at risk of losing its economic superpower status to China, the world's most populous country.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Bannon said. \"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years, and it's going to be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"\n\nHe continued, \"To me, the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon's plan to counter China's increasingly strong economic influence is to file a complaint under Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act against Chinese coercion of technology transfers from American corporations doing business there and follow-up complaints against Chinese steel and aluminum dumping. \"We're going to run the tables on these guys. Robert E. Lee, the commander of the Confederate Army in the 19th-century American Civil War.\n\nOne woman was killed when a suspected far-right sympathiser drove a car into a crowd of counter-protestors. In the days following the incident, President Donald Trump made a series of remarks -- some off the cuff -- that were strongly rebuked by both Democrats and Republicans.\n\nIn the interview, Bannon was asked if there was a connection between the economic nationalism that he supports and the white nationalism seen in Charlottesville.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers,\" he said. \"It's a fringe element. far-right news website Breitbart, is a controversial figure within the White House.\n\nA source close to Bannon told CNN he did not believe he was being interviewed when he spoke with the co-founder {"timeCrawl": "22:43:00", "uri": "710578718", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T22:43:00Z", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "source": {"title": "yahoo.com", "uri": "yahoo.com", "id": "228"}, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/why-bannon-won-apos-t-221120271.html", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "By Monday evening, the paroxysm of extremist violence at a Unite the Right rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, had been condemned by President Donald J. Trump, Vice President Mike Pence and Attorney General Jeff Sessions, not to mention a coalition of congressional Republicans and Democrats that included both conservative Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Vermont socialist Senator Bernie Sanders.\n\nBut one voice was notably missing: that of Stephen K. Bannon, the White House chief political strategist who has been described as having a \"mind meld\" with the president, especially on issues of national identity, trade and immigration.\n\nRelated: Will Donald Trump fire Steve Bannon?\n\nSteve Bannon, Donald Trump's chief strategist, leaves the Rose Garden after the president announces his decision to pull out of the Paris climate agreement at the White House in Washington, D.C., on June 1. Chip Somodevilla/Getty\n\nFrom Saturday afternoon until Tuesday evening, Newsweek sent more than a half-dozen requests for comment to Bannon, as well as to the White House press office and to two representatives of CapitalHQ, a publicity firm that reportedly represents Bannon. Those requests asked Bannon if he would condemn the violence in Charlottesville. Newsweek also asked how Bannon would describe his relationship to the groups that participated in Unite the Right.\n\nBannon did not respond to any of these queries. Nor did anyone else presumably authorized to speak on his behalf, suggesting that a media avoidance strategy was in the works.\n\nThe silence isn't surprising, since Bannon rarely talks (on the record) to the mainstream media, which he has described as an \"opposition party\" relative to the Trump administration. Many observers point to a seeming affinity between Bannon, a self-described \"economic nationalist\" who presided over far-right clearinghouse Breitbart News, and the extremists groups that descended on Charlottesville over the weekend to protest the removal of a Confederate statue.\n\nAfter chaos swept through that town, the hashtag #FireBannon trended on Twitter, as both liberals and establishment conservatives called for the rumpled nationalist to be expelled from the White House.\n\nOn Monday, The New York Times reported that Bannon's status was embattled. He had \"consulted with the president repeatedly over the weekend as Mr. Trump struggled to respond to the neo-Nazi rally in Charlottesville, Virginia. In general, Mr. Bannon has cautioned the president not to criticize far-right activists too severely for fear of antagonizing a small but energetic part of his base.\"\n\nIt was Bannon's influence, presumably, that led Trump to issue a tepid statement on Saturday afternoon, in which he said that \"many sides\" were responsible for the deaths and 19 injuries in Charlottesville. That statement was widely condemned, leading to a more forceful one on Monday, in which Trump more forcefully criticized Saturday's malefactors.\n\nAccording to the Times, whose Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush, widely considered the best-sourced reporters on the Trump administration, his reticence in speaking out on Charlottesville has led to \"new pressure from Mr. Trump's critics to dismiss Mr. Bannon,\" as he has \"become a major liability.\"\n\nIt's impossible to say just how much Bannon identifies with the far right, if at all. Although he likes to portray himself as an above-the-fray intellectual, Bannon has been accused of anti-Semitism by an ex-wife, and he made an anti-Asian statement on his radio program. His favorite books are said to include The Camp of the Saints, an anti-immigrant French novel, and the works of Italian fascist Julius Evola. Bannon has reportedly disparaged centrist members of the Trump administration as \"globalists\" and \"cucks,\" resorting to the kind of juvenile vitriol one doesn't often hear from a senior government official.\n\nDuring a Wednesday press conference that was supposed to be focused on infrastructure, Trump took questions on Charlottesville. He said he had not consulted Bannon about how to respond to Saturday's violence and called him \"a good man.\"\n\nHowever, Trump would not offer his chief strategist the kind of unequivocal support that could credibly pass for job security. \"We'll see,\" he said about Bannon's future prospects at the White House.\n\nRelated Articles\n\nAnthony Scaramucci to Stephen Colbert: Trump Is Compassionate, Bannon Doesn't Belong in White HouseRight-Wing Pundit Dinesh D'Souza Visits Bannon and Gorka in White House to Tout New Book Comparing Liberals to Nazis'Devil's Bargain,' About Steve Bannon, Is Addictive, If Not Definitive", "id": "9577161", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Why Bannon Won't Condemn the Charlottesville Violence", "image": {"timeCrawl": "15:30:00", "uri": "710964373", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:30:00Z", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "source": {"title": "yahoo.com", "uri": "yahoo.com", "id": "228"}, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/steve-bannon-gives-rare-blistering-093939280.html", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "Steve Bannon has described the far right as a \"collection of clowns\" and said he would \"crush the Democrats\" as he attempts to cling on to his position at the White House.\n\nDonald Trump's chief strategist made a series of controversial remarks to American Prospect, a left-wing political magazine, in which he discussed the on-going issues and feuds within the Trump administration, the violence in Charlottesville, US-China trade policy and possibly military intervention in North Korea.\n\nThere have been renewed calls from both the left and right for Mr Bannon, the former editor of Breitbart News and the man who many feel is the mastermind of Mr Trump's nationalist agenda, to be removed from his post.\n\nDuring the wide-ranging interview, Mr Bannon went on the offensive and said he hoped those on the left continued to focus on race so he could \"crush\" them.\n\n\"The longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em. I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats,\" Mr Bannon told American Prospect.\n\nHe also called the far right \"irrelevant\" as he responded to the suggestion that Mr Trump had refused to condemn the \"ugly white nationalism epitomised by the racist violence in Charlottesville\".\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism - it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more ... These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nIn his comments on China, Mr Bannon claimed he was moving people around the Trump administration to tackle what he described as an \"economic war\" with the Asian superpower.\n\n\"I'm changing out people at East Asian Defense; I'm getting hawks in. I'm getting Susan Thornton [acting head of East Asian and Pacific Affairs] out at State. That's a fight I fight every day here. We're still fighting.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China. It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"\n\n\"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it. Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nMr Bannon claimed he was unaware the conversation was on the record but his comments have come only days after Mr Trump declined to offer any reassurances on the future of his chief strategist.\n\nWhen asked if Mr Bannon would remain in his position the President replied \"we'll see\" but did scrutinise the media coverage he receives.\n\n\"I like Mr Bannon. He's a friend of mine. He's a good person and I think the press treats him, frankly, very unfairly,\" Mr Trump said.\n\nIt has been a rather turbulent period in the White House with a series of resignations and sackings at the highest level.\n\nMr Trump removed both Reince Priebus, his then chief of staff, and Anthony Scaramucci, briefly his communications director, in the space of four days.\n\nSean Spicer, who was Mr I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more ... These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nWhile talking about the far-right, Bannon took the opportunity to slam the Democrats' fondness for tackling \"identity politics.\"\n\n\"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em,\" Bannon said. \"I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"\n\nIn the interview, Bannon also seemed to counter President Trump's incendiary comments about unleashing \"fire and fury\" upon North Korea if the rogue nation continues to threaten the U.S.\n\n\"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it,\" he said. \"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that ten million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nBannon did have harsh words for China, which he says is at war with the U.S. -- economically, that is. He added that the U.S. is at risk of losing its economic superpower status to the world's most populous country.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Bannon said. \"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path. On Korea, they're just tapping us along. It's just a sideshow.\"\n\nHe continued, \"To me, the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, ten years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nBannon's plan to counter China's increasingly strong economic influence is to file a complaint under Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act against Chinese coercion of technology transfers from American corporations doing business there, and follow-up complaints against steel and aluminum dumping. \"We're going to run the tables on these guys. {"timeCrawl": "12:31:00", "uri": "710875885", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:31:00Z", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "source": {"title": "POLITICO", "uri": "politico.eu", "id": "19273"}, "url": "http://www.politico.eu/article/steve-bannon-white-house-vows-to-shake-up-staffing/", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "White House chief strategist takes different position to Donald Trump on North Korea.\n\nWhite House chief strategist Steve Bannon pledged to shake up staffing at the Departments of Defense and State and said his adversaries, both inside the White House and out of it, are \"wetting themselves\" at the prospect of his plans.\n\nHe also appeared to take on National Economic Council chair Gary Cohn, and said the U.S. must ready itself for an \"economic war with China\" that has already begun.\n\nBannon, in the same interview with the American Prospect, labeled hate groups of the type that marched in a deadly rally over the weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia, as \"a collection of clowns.\" But he also said the cultural issues raised by the hate groups had lured Democrats into a rhetorical trap that would allow Republicans to succeed.\n\nOn North Korea, Bannon struck out a position different from that of his boss, President Donald Trump, telling the American Prospect, a liberal magazine, that \"there's no military solution\" to the repressive regime's nuclear program and that the U.S. should \"forget it.\" Trump has said that the U.S. will not allow North Korea to obtain a nuclear weapon capable of striking the continental U.S. and has pointedly refused to take a military option off the table.\n\n\"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us,\" Bannon said.\n\nBut North Korea, Bannon continued, was \"just a sideshow\" on which China is \"just tapping us along\" relative to the economic battle he sees brewing with the Chinese. He predicted that either the U.S. or China would be the world's dominant nation in the next quarter-century, \"and it's gonna be them if we go down this path.\"\n\nBannon told his interviewer that part of his plan to turn the economic tables on the Chinese government would be to issue complaints under the 1974 Trade Act, a move that he said had other government officials \"wetting themselves\" with concern over upsetting the international trading system or removing the possibility that China might help tamp down North Korea.\n\n\"To me,\" Bannon said, \"the economic war with China is everything. And we have to be maniacally focused on that. If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nPushing his get-tough-with-China approach is \"a fight I fight every day here.\" At least part of his strategy, he said, would be to change out staff members at the State Department and Department of Defense, specifically naming one official he planned to remove.\n\n\"I'm changing out people at East Asian Defense; I'm getting hawks in. I'm getting Susan Thornton out at State,\" Bannon said, naming the acting director of East Asian and Pacific affairs at the State Department. \"We're still fighting. One woman was killed and several of her fellow counter-protesters were injured when a car plowed through a crowd. In the days following the incident, President Donald Trump made a series of remarks -- some off the cuff -- that were strongly rebuked by politicians from both sides of the aisle.\n\nThe former editor of the far-right news website Breitbart is a controversial figure within the White House.\n\nEarlier this week, Rep. Carlos Curbelo, R-Florida, named Bannon and Stephen Miller as individuals he thought were trying to accommodate the alt-right or white nationalists from within the West Wing, and advised the President to stop listening to them.\n\nBannon and the White House did not immediately respond to CNN's requests for comment.\n\nBut Bannon's comments to the Prospect pushed back on that notion.\n\n\"It's a fringe element,\" Bannon told the magazine's co-founder Robert Kuttner about white nationalists within Trump's base. \"I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more.\"\n\nHe added: \"These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nKuttner said that Bannon never asked for his remarks to be off the record.\n\n\"The question of whether the phone call was on or off the record never came up. This is also puzzling, since Steve Bannon is not exactly Bambi when it comes to dealing with the press. {"timeCrawl": "10:21:00", "uri": "710816707", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:21:00Z", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "source": {"title": "http://www.hindustantimes.com/", "uri": "hindustantimes.com", "id": "294"}, "url": "http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/us-at-economic-war-with-china-says-trump-advisor-steve-bannon/story-hbkrNYTztHpd3WmyijuwkJ.html", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "The United States is in an economic war with China, US President Donald Trump's chief political strategist has said, warning Washington is losing the fight but is about to hit China hard over unfair trade practices.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Steve Bannon told US news site prospect.org in an interview published in Wednesday.\n\n\"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nChinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying said she had seen the report, and reiterated the essence of the China-U.S. trade relationship is mutually beneficial.\n\n\"In reality, China and the United States' long term cooperation has brought about real benefits for both countries' peoples, any unbiased person will clearly see this fact,\" she told a daily news briefing in Beijing.\n\n\"We have also said before, a trade war has no future. A trade war does not serve the interests of any party, as fighting a trade war will not produce a winner. We hope that relevant parties can stop viewing issues of the 21st century with a 19th- or 20th-century mentality.\"\n\nBannon said the United States would use Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act against Chinese coercion of technology transfers from US corporations doing business in China and follow up with complaints against steel and aluminium dumping, according to prospect.org.\n\nOn Monday, Trump authorised an inquiry into China's alleged theft of intellectual property in the first direct trade measure by his administration against Beijing.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" said Bannon, who acknowledged he was battling trade doves within the US administration.\n\nHe said there was no reason to go soft on China in order to get Beijing's support over North Korea because he believed China would do little more to rein in Pyongyang.\n\nBannon said he might consider a deal in which China got North Korea to freeze its nuclear build-up with verifiable inspections and the United States removed its troops from the Korean peninsula, but such a deal seemed remote, prospect.org reported.\n\nIn contrast to Trump's threat of \"fire and fury\" against North Korea, Bannon said: \"There's no military solution, forget it.\"\n\n\"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about ...\"\n\nAsked about any connection between his economic nationalism and white nationalism in the United States, and in particular the racist violence in Charlottesville, Bannon said: \"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element.\"\n\n\"I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more. These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nHowever, Bannon, who formerly led the right-wing website Breitbart, said focusing on race would help the Republicans politically.\n\n\"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em. I want them to talk about racism every day. If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"", "id": "9661845", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "US at 'economic war' {"timeCrawl": "11:17:00", "uri": "710842453", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:12:00Z", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "source": {"title": "BBC", "uri": "bbc.com", "id": "489"}, "url": "http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-40958329", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "The chief White House strategist Steve Bannon has attacked white nationalists as \"clowns\" as the fallout from violent protests in Charlottesville continues.\n\nMr Bannon once headed the far-right Breitbart News, seen as both a major channel for nationalism and key in helping Donald Trump win election.\n\nBut he told The American Prospect: \"Ethno-nationalism - it's losers\".\n\nQuestions surround Mr Bannon's future, with President Trump refusing to say if he had confidence in him.\n\nMr Trump has reportedly been urged to fire Mr Bannon, who in his role has enjoyed direct access to the president and whose influence has been seen in decisions like the US withdrawing from the Paris climate accord.\n\nAt a news conference this week Mr Trump would only say \"we'll see\" when it came to Mr Bannon's future.\n\nMr Trump is under fire for his response to Saturday's clashes between far-right and counter protesters in Charlottesville, Virginia, in which he blamed \"both sides\" for the violence.\n\nThe rally, attended by neo-Nazis and white supremacists, was in protest at the removal of a statue of Robert E Lee, a general who fought for the pro-slavery Confederacy during the US Civil War.\n\nA memorial was held on Wednesday for Heather Heyer, a 32-year-old woman killed when a suspected far-right sympathiser drove a car into a crowd of counter-protesters.\n\nMeanwhile Apple chief executive Tim Cook has become the latest business leader to criticise President Trump, saying he did not agree there was a \"moral equivalence\" between white supremacists and \"those who oppose them\".\n\nIn his interview with the US magazine, Mr Bannon was asked if there was a connection between the economic nationalism that he supports and the white nationalism seen in Charlottesville.\n\n\"Ethno-nationalism - it's losers,\" he said. \"It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more.\"\n\n\"These guys are a collection of clowns,\" he added.\n\nMr Bannon has distanced himself from \"ethno-nationalism\" before, telling the New York Times his interest in nationalism stems from wanting to curb the negative effects of globalisation.\n\nNorth Korea: Despite Donald Trump threatening North Korea with \"fire and fury\", in his interview Mr Bannon said there was no military solution to the crisis over the Pyongyang's nuclear programme.\n\n\"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about, there's no military solution here, they got us,\" he said.\n\nChina: Mr Bannon said if anything North Korea was just a \"sideshow\" to the real challenge the US is facing - \"economic war\" with China.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, ten years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover,\" he said, adding that the US intended to challenge China over intellectual property rights, and iron and steel dumping.\n\nIn response, the Chinese foreign ministry said joint trade brought \"real benefits\" to both sides, Reuters news agency reported. \"We hope that relevant parties can stop viewing issues of the 21st Century with a 19th or 20th Century mentality,\" a spokesperson said.\n\nWhite House infighting: Mr Bannon admitted he was facing an internal {"timeCrawl": "09:38:00", "uri": "710797237", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T09:38:00Z", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "source": {"title": "timesofmalta.com", "uri": "timesofmalta.com", "id": "818"}, "url": "https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20170817/world/trump-adviser-bannon-says-us-in-economic-war-with-china.655846", "eventUri": "eng-3367630", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3367630", "body": "The United States is in an economic war with China, US President Donald Trump's chief political strategist has said, warning Washington is losing the fight but is about to hit China hard over unfair trade practices.\n\n\"We're at economic war with China,\" Steve Bannon told US news site prospect.org in an interview published on Wednesday.\n\n\"It's in all their literature. They're not shy about saying what they're doing. One of us is going to be a hegemon in 25 or 30 years and it's gonna be them if we go down this path,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\n\"If we continue to lose it, we're five years away, I think, 10 years at the most, of hitting an inflection point from which we'll never be able to recover.\"\n\nChinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying said she had seen the report, and reiterated the essence of the China-U.S. trade relationship is mutually beneficial.\n\n\"In reality, China and the United States' long term cooperation has brought about real benefits for both countries' peoples, any unbiased person will clearly see this fact,\" she told a daily news briefing in Beijing.\n\n\"We have also said before, a trade war has no future. A trade war does not serve the interests of any party, as fighting a trade war will not produce a winner. We hope that relevant parties can stop viewing issues of the 21st century with a 19th- or 20th-century mentality.\"\n\nBannon said the United States would use Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act against Chinese coercion of technology transfers from US corporations doing business in China and follow up with complaints against steel and aluminium dumping, according to prospect.org.\n\nOn Monday, Trump authorised an inquiry into China's alleged theft of intellectual property in the first direct trade measure by his administration against Beijing.\n\n\"We're going to run the tables on these guys. We've come to the conclusion that they're in an economic war and they're crushing us,\" said Bannon, who acknowledged he was battling trade doves within the US administration.\n\nHe said there was no reason to go soft on China in order to get Beijing's support over North Korea because he believed China would do little more to rein in Pyongyang.\n\nBannon said he might consider a deal in which China got North Korea to freeze its nuclear build-up with verifiable inspections and the United States removed its troops from the Korean peninsula, but such a deal seemed remote, prospect.org reported.\n\nIn contrast to Trump's threat of \"fire and fury\" against North Korea, Bannon said: \"There's no military solution, forget it.\"\n\n\"Until somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don't die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons, I don't know what you're talking about ...\"\n\nAsked about any connection between his economic nationalism and white nationalism in the United States, and in particular the racist violence in Charlottesville, Bannon said: \"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element.\"\n\n\"I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more. These guys are a collection of clowns.\"\n\nHowever, Bannon, who formerly led the right-wing website Breitbart, said focusing on race would help the Republicans politically.\n\n\"The Democrats, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em. I want them to talk about racism every day. The opinions expressed in this commentary are his own.\n\n(CNN)Everything we know about Steve Bannon's interview with Robert Kuttner, editor of the left-leaning American Prospect magazine, suggests that Bannon -- President Trump's chief strategist -- was being entirely candid about his political thinking in an unsolicited phone call to Kuttner.\n\nThat's a troubling thought. Bannon described a positive political advantage for the White House following Trump's \"both sides\" statements that indirectly supported the white supremacists responsible for the recent violence in Charlottesville, Virginia.\"Ethno-nationalism -- it's losers. It's a fringe element. I think the media plays it up too much, and we gotta help crush it, you know, uh, help crush it more. These guys are a collection of clowns,\" Bannon told Kuttner -- a cynical dismissal from the former editor of Breitbart news who last year gleefully described his media organization as \"the platform for the alt-right,\" that same \"fringe\" movement.And while military leaders, business titans and Republican former presidents have all taken pains to distance themselves from Trump's comments about the violence in Charlottesville, Bannon seems to be embracing the controversy as helpful to the White House. \"The Democrats -- the longer they talk about identity politics, I got 'em. I want them to talk about racism every day,\" Bannon said to Kuttner. \"If the left is focused on race and identity, and we go with economic nationalism, we can crush the Democrats.\"Read MoreThose are the stunningly irresponsible words of a man willing to shrug off the possible ramifications of growing racial division -- divisions that cost a young woman her life -- in order to reap political advantage.A recent poll of US adults found that 27% think the President's remarks about far-right extremists were \"strong enough,\" compared with the 52% majority who think Trump's comments weren't strong enough.But as Bannon is making clear, the White House sees a path to victory by leaving the difficult issue of race relations to the Democrats and focusing on jobs and the economy. It's hard to imagine a more cynical ploy. Bannon has tried to spin his interview with Kuttner as a strategy designed to draw media attention away from Trump, but that doesn't ring true.Democrats should be certain to recognize the game that Trump and Bannon are playing. The insensitive, inconsistent comments coming from the White House, it seems, are part of a plan to allow white nationalist \"clowns\" to bait Democrats into complaining about racism instead of fighting for tax and investment policies that help working class Americans.Democrats should remind Americans that it is they who are able to simultaneously fight against intolerance and develop policies that resonate with working-class households.
